A New Chapter in American Democracy: President Biden's Inaugural Address Emphasizes Unity and Hope Amid Challenges

Ladies and Gentlemen,

I stand before you today, humbled and honored, as the 46th President of the United States of America. It is with a heart full of gratitude and a spirit filled with hope that I address you all on this momentous day - Democracy's Day.

Democracy has prevailed. It has triumphed over adversity and division. It has weathered the storms of discord and doubt. And today, we gather to witness its enduring power and resilience.

I want to acknowledge the presence of my predecessors, past presidents who have led our great nation through times of peace and war, prosperity and hardship. I extend my deepest respect and admiration to each one of them. Among them, I wish to specifically mention former President Jimmy Carter. His lifetime of service to our country and the world is an inspiration to us all.

Ladies and Gentlemen,

We find ourselves at a crossroads in American history. We face numerous challenges that test the very fabric of our democracy. We have witnessed the peaceful transfer of power, a testament to the strength of our institutions and the steadfast commitment of the American people to uphold the rule of law.

Unity is crucial for our nation's future. We may have our differences, but we are all Americans. We must remember that we are stronger together than we are apart. Let us put aside our political affiliations and work together to overcome the challenges we face.

Our country is grappling with the COVID-19 pandemic. We have lost too many lives and livelihoods. We must come together to defeat this virus and rebuild our economy.

Racial justice remains an unfulfilled promise. We must confront the systemic racism that plagues our society and work towards equality and justice for all.

Climate change poses an existential threat to our planet. We must act urgently to reduce our carbon footprint and transition to renewable energy sources.

Political extremism threatens the very foundation of our democracy. We must reject the lies and manipulated facts that fuel division and hatred.

Ladies and Gentlemen,

I pledge to be a President for all Americans. Regardless of your political affiliation, I will work tirelessly to ensure that every American has the opportunity to live a life of dignity and respect.

Truth is the cornerstone of our democracy. We must reject the lies and misinformation that seek to divide us. We must embrace the truth and work together to build a brighter future for ourselves and our children.

I call upon you, my fellow Americans, to join me in this endeavor. Let us come together, united in our love for this great nation and our commitment to its ideals.

We have faced adversity before, and we have always emerged stronger and more resilient. We will do so again. We will overcome these challenges, and we will write a new chapter in American history.

Ladies and Gentlemen, I believe in America. I believe in its people. I believe in its strength and resilience. And I believe that together, we can overcome any challenge that comes our way.

May God bless you all, and may God bless the United States of America.

Fact Check: Biden's Inauguration – Limited Crowds, Security Threats, and Misinformation

The 2021 presidential inauguration of Joe Biden faced unprecedented challenges due to the ongoing coronavirus pandemic and heightened security concerns following the Capitol riot. In this fact check article, we will separate fact from fiction regarding key aspects of the ceremony.

The coronavirus pandemic forced significant limitations on the inauguration ceremony. Crowd sizes were restricted, and attendees were required to wear masks and maintain social distancing to prevent the spread of COVID-19.

A notable absence at the inauguration was former President Donald Trump, who declined to attend the event. This marked a departure from tradition, as every living president has attended the inauguration of their successor since 1869.

Washington D.C. experienced heightened security following the pro-Trump riot on January 6, 2021. Thousands of National Guard troops and law enforcement officers were deployed to secure the city and prevent any potential unrest.

Misinformation surrounding the 2020 election and Inauguration Day has been prevalent, with false claims spreading on social media platforms. One such claim was that flags were added to the National Mall to make the inauguration look less empty.

This claim was rated as "missing context" due to the pandemic and security measures in place. In reality, the flags were part of a public art exhibition called "Fields of Honor," representing Americans unable to attend the inauguration due to COVID-19 restrictions.

Biden's inauguration maintained strict coronavirus precautions, continuing practices from his presidential campaign. These measures included virtual events, limited attendance, and mask-wearing.

The absence of large crowds marked a significant change from traditional inauguration ceremonies, which typically attract hundreds of thousands of spectators.

Another false claim that circulated was that the National Mall was intentionally flooded to make the inauguration look less impressive. However, this was debunked as there was no evidence to support the claim.

Additionally, there were allegations that Biden's inauguration was not a legitimate transfer of power and that the election results were fraudulent. These claims have been extensively debunked by numerous fact-checking organizations and courts.

A common myth was that Biden only received 8,000 votes in the 2020 election. In reality, he received over 81 million votes, making it the most votes ever received by a presidential candidate in U.S. history.

Misinformation about the National Guard's role during the inauguration also emerged, with some claiming that they were being used for crowd control or even detaining Americans. However, the National Guard was there solely for security purposes.

A false claim that went viral was that the National Mall was being used as a detention camp for protestors. This was debunked, as there was no evidence to support the claim and the National Mall remained open to the public throughout the inauguration weekend.

There were also allegations that Biden was not a legitimate president due to his age or citizenship status. These claims have been extensively debunked, as Biden is a natural-born U.S. citizen and met the age requirement to serve as president.

Another false claim was that Biden's inauguration was funded by foreign governments. However, all inauguration funds came from private donations and the federal government.

Misinformation surrounding the COVID-19 vaccines and their distribution during the inauguration also emerged. There were claims that the vaccines were not effective or that they were being used for population control. These claims have been debunked by numerous scientific studies and health organizations.

As the new administration begins, it is crucial to remain vigilant against misinformation and to fact-check claims before sharing them. The ongoing pandemic and heightened security concerns have made it more important than ever to separate fact from fiction.

In conclusion, the 2021 presidential inauguration faced unique challenges due to the coronavirus pandemic and security concerns. Misinformation surrounding the event was rampant, with false claims about crowd sizes, flags, election results, and various other aspects. By fact-checking these claims and separating fact from fiction, we can ensure a more informed public discourse.

Biden Takes Oath as President Amid Heightened Security and COVID-19 Precautions, Trump Departs White House

Washington CNN – President Joe Biden was sworn in as the 46th President of the United States on Wednesday, taking the oath of office on the West Front of the U.S. Capitol, surrounded by a heavy security presence and COVID-19 precautions in the wake of last month's insurrection and the ongoing pandemic.

Outgoing President Donald Trump, who did not attend the ceremony, left the White House for the last time as commander-in-chief earlier in the day, expressing gratitude for the opportunity to serve.

"It's been an amazing journey, the last four years," Trump said in remarks at Joint Base Andrews before boarding Air Force One for the final time as president. "It's been an honor and privilege, and I will always be grateful to the American people for the wonderful opportunity that they've given me and our family."

Biden and Vice President Kamala Harris attended morning services at the Cathedral of St. Matthew the Apostle with their families and Congressional leaders, marking the historic nature of Harris' election as the first female, first Black, and first South Asian vice president of the United States.

Biden, sworn in by Chief Justice John Roberts using a family Bible, pledged to be a "president for all Americans."

"This is America's day. This is democracy's day," Biden said in his inaugural address. "A day of history and hope, of renewal and resolve. Through a crucible for the ages, America has been tested anew. And in this test, we saw failure, we saw perseverance, and we saw belated but powerful resolve."

During his remarks, Trump did not mention Biden by name but wished the incoming administration "great luck" and "great success." Melania Trump, the former first lady, also issued a statement congratulating the Bidens.

"Being your First Lady was my greatest honor," Melania Trump said in a statement. "I wish the new First Lady and your family the very best. I am rooting for you and will be in your prayers. God bless you and God bless the United States of America."

Following the ceremony, Biden signed his first presidential documents, including an Inauguration Day Proclamation and nominations. He and Harris then participated in a wreath-laying ceremony at Arlington National Cemetery with former presidents and their spouses.

Biden also signed over a dozen executive actions, many of which reversed Trump policies, including rejoining the Paris climate accord, extending eviction moratoriums, and reversing the travel ban on several Muslim-majority countries.

"Today, on this January day, my whole soul is in this: bringing America together, uniting our people, and restoring the soul of our nation," Biden said in his executive orders.

Trump's absence from the ceremony was a stark contrast to his inauguration in 2017, when he became the first president in more than a century to skip the traditional inaugural luncheon following the swearing-in ceremony.

As Biden took the oath of office, a sense of relief and optimism washed over the nation's capital, with many hoping for a return to normalcy and unity following a tumultuous four years under Trump.

"We're here to witness the peaceful transfer of power," Biden supporter Katie Massey told CNN. "It's historic, but it's just what's supposed to happen. It's what makes us who we are as a country."

Trump's refusal to concede the election and his false claims of widespread voter fraud fueled the deadly insurrection at the U.S. Capitol on January 6, leaving five people dead and prompting heightened security measures for the inauguration.

Despite the challenges facing the new administration, Biden emphasized respect and unity among White House staff.

"Let's get to work," Biden said as he signed his first executive orders. "This is a new day for America."

As Biden and Harris took their places in the Oval Office for the first time, they were greeted by a White House staff that had been asked to sign a code of conduct pledging to treat each other with respect and dignity.

"We're going to be an administration that's going to be focused on bringing the country together," Biden senior adviser Cedric Richmond said. "It's going to be an administration that's going to be focused on getting things done for the American people."

Biden's inauguration marked the end of an era and the beginning of a new chapter in American history. With the weight of the presidency now on his shoulders, Biden pledged to be a "president for all Americans" and work to heal the divisions that have plagued the country in recent years.

"We must end this uncivil war that pits red against blue, rural versus urban, conservative versus liberal," Biden said in his inaugural address. "We can do this if we open our souls instead of hardening our hearts."

As the sun set on the National Mall, the sounds of fireworks filled the air, signaling a new beginning for the United States under the leadership of President Joe Biden and Vice President Kamala Harris.

"We have come so far, but we still have far to go," Biden said in his closing remarks. "We'll press forward with speed and urgency, for we have much to do in this winter of peril and significant possibility."

Biden Sworn In as President, Calls for Unity Amid Crises; Harris Makes History

WASHINGTON (AP) – Joe Biden was sworn in as the 46th president of the United States on Wednesday, emphasizing democracy's triumph in the face of unprecedented challenges and calling for unity in a deeply divided nation. Kamala Harris made history as the first woman, first Black person, and first person of South Asian descent elected to the vice presidency.

Biden's inauguration took place under heightened security and without crowds due to the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic and the recent siege at the U.S. Capitol. Over 200,000 American flags were planted on the National Mall to represent those who couldn't attend.

In his speech, Biden indirectly rebuked his predecessor, former President Donald Trump, focusing instead on democracy, unity, and the challenges America faces, including the coronavirus pandemic, economic strain, and racial injustice.

After being sworn in by Chief Justice John Roberts, Biden signed a series of executive actions, including rejoining the Paris Climate Accords and instituting a mask mandate on federal property. Former Presidents Bill Clinton, George W. Bush, and Barack Obama attended the inauguration, highlighting bipartisan support for the new administration.

Biden enters office with a plan for an ambitious first 100 days, focusing on combating the pandemic and providing economic relief. The new president's agenda includes confirming his Cabinet nominees, issuing a mask mandate nationwide, and rejoining the World Health Organization.

Performances by Lady Gaga, Garth Brooks, and other artists during the ceremony emphasized national unity and healing. The absence of crowds and the presence of a large security force marked this as an unusual inauguration, with the National Guard deployed around the city.

Biden's inauguration comes at a pivotal moment in American history, with the country grappling with the ongoing pandemic, economic uncertainty, and deep political divisions. The new administration faces the daunting task of uniting a divided nation and addressing the crises at hand.

In his speech, Biden acknowledged the gravity of the situation and expressed optimism for the future. "We've learned again that democracy is precious," he said. "Democracy is fragile. And at this hour, my friends, democracy has prevailed."

Trump Defies Tradition, Skips Biden's Inauguration, Seen as Act of Defiance

WASHINGTON (AP) – In a break from tradition, outgoing President Donald Trump announced on Thursday that he will not attend President-elect Joe Biden's inauguration, further fueling concerns about the peaceful transfer of power and amplifying his false claims of widespread voter fraud.

Trump's decision was met with criticism from both sides of the aisle, with some viewing it as an act of defiance and a blow to the democratic process. Biden, in a statement, called Trump an "embarrassment" but welcomed his vice president, Mike Pence, to the ceremony.

"It's a good thing," Biden said during an event in Delaware on Thursday.

Historically, outgoing and incoming presidents have attended each other's inaugurations, symbolizing a smooth transition of power. Former presidents Barack Obama, George W. Bush, and Bill Clinton, along with the ailing Jimmy Carter, are expected to attend Biden's inauguration on Jan. 20.

Trump's absence comes amidst ongoing discussions about his second impeachment and after he was banned from Twitter for spreading misinformation about the election results. The president has continued to falsely claim that he won the election and has alleged widespread voter fraud, despite no evidence to support these claims.

Sen. Rick Scott (R-FL) weighed in on Trump's decision, telling CNN: "I think it's a mistake for him not to go. He should go."

Trump's spokesperson, Judd Deere, said in a statement that the president "will not participate in a joint session of Congress on January 6th that was never planned nor confirmed by the President or his team."

Devin O'Malley, spokesperson for Vice President Pence, said in a statement: "The Vice President remains committed to supporting the 23rd Amendment and the Constitution. He will attend the inauguration ceremony on January 20."

Historian Douglas Brinkley, speaking to CNN, suggested Trump's absence portrays him as a "sore loser" and undermines democracy.

"I think it's a very sad day for the country," Brinkley said. "A peaceful transition of power is important. He's just an embarrassment to the country."

Concerns about Trump's actions in his final days have led to discussions about invoking the 25th Amendment or impeachment. House Speaker Nancy Pelosi (D-CA) said on Thursday that she will be bringing a resolution to impeach Trump to the House floor next week.

Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell (R-KY), however, has indicated that the Senate will not take up an impeachment trial during the lame-duck session.

Trump's refusal to concede and attend Biden's inauguration adds to the uncertainty surrounding the transition of power and the future of American democracy.

Armed Protests and Security Clampdown: FBI Warns of Threats Ahead of Biden's Inauguration

As the inauguration of President-elect Joe Biden approaches on January 20, the FBI has issued a stern warning of possible armed protests in all 50 states and the US capital. This comes as state officials prepare for potentially violent demonstrations in support of outgoing President Donald Trump.

FBI Director Christopher Wray stated, "Armed protests are being planned at all 50 state capitols from this week through Inauguration Day. There are also plans for armed protests in Washington, D.C."

In Texas, Department of Public Safety Director Steve McCraw urged caution. "We are seeing a growing number of individuals expressing their First Amendment rights through violence, destruction of property, and assaults on law enforcement," McCraw warned.

Michigan State Police Director Joe Gasper echoed similar concerns, stating, "We have credible information of a potential plot to breach the Michigan State Capitol complex." In response, the Michigan Capitol has been closed, and a fence has been erected around the building.

In Illinois, Governor JB Pritzker activated 1,000 National Guard members, while in Virginia, Democratic US Representative Don Beyer tweeted, "Virginia National Guard troops are on the streets of Richmond today. They are here to protect us. Let's hope it doesn't come to that in DC next week."

Meanwhile, a man named Wesley Allen Beeler was arrested at a security checkpoint near the US Capitol with a loaded handgun and over 500 rounds of ammunition. Beeler claimed it was "an honest mistake" and that he was a private security guard who got lost. "I didn't realize I was so close to the Capitol," Beeler told authorities.

The FBI also warned of potential violent protests at all 50 state capitol buildings starting on Saturday and lasting through Biden's inauguration. The anti-government "Boogaloo" movement plans to hold rallies in all 50 states on Sunday.

Thousands of armed National Guard troops are on the streets of Washington, DC, ahead of the inauguration. House Intelligence Chairman Adam Schiff (D-CA) praised the preparations, stating, "The security measures being put in place are necessary and appropriate to ensure the safety of the incoming president and the American people."

However, House Homeland Security Chairman Bennie Thompson (D-MS) expressed concern over the potential for a repeat of the January 6 riot at the US Capitol. "We cannot afford another attack on our democracy," Thompson warned.

House Oversight Chairwoman Carolyn Maloney (D-NY) and House Judiciary Committee Chairman Jerrold Nadler (D-NY) have opened a review of the January 6 riot, with Nadler stating, "We will get to the bottom of this."

As the country braces for potential unrest, authorities are urging citizens to remain vigilant and report any suspicious activity. The FBI can be reached at 1-800-CALL-FBI (1-800-225-5324) or tips.fbi.gov.

A House Divided: Biden's Unity Call Amidst Inauguration's heightened Security and Fears of MAGA Violence

As Joe Biden took the oath of office on the Capitol steps, the backdrop of national unity was contrasted by the heightened security measures put in place due to fears of more MAGA violence. The January 6 Capitol attack, spurred by former President Donald Trump, has left Washington on high alert for potential further violence during the inauguration.

FBI Director Christopher Wray addressed these concerns during a press conference, stating, "Based on what we've seen over the last couple of months, we're taking it seriously. We've been working around the clock to ensure that we're doing everything in our power to protect the event." The FBI has warned of the threat of QAnon followers potentially disrupting the inauguration, including plans to disguise as National Guard troops.

QAnon believers, who were among the MAGA extremists storming the Capitol, were warned of scheming disruptions for the inauguration. One QAnon follower was reportedly overheard saying, "We're going to blend in. We're going to look like the National Guard. We're going to have guns. We're going to have radios. We're going to have helmets."

The tension over the transition of power is exacerbated by concerns of insurrectionists posing as security forces. Christopher Wray emphasized the need for vigilance against various potential threats, including armed protests and lone wolf threats. "We're doing everything we can to prevent that from happening," Wray said.

Extremist involvement in law enforcement and the military raises additional concerns, as individuals with military backgrounds were among those participating in the January 6 riot. The Pentagon is intensifying efforts to eliminate far-right extremists from its ranks, in light of the heightened security risks. Two Army National Guard members with ties to fringe right-wing militias were removed from the inauguration security mission.

Lieutenant General Walter Piatt, the Army's deputy chief of staff for intelligence, acknowledged the challenges, stating, "A healthy democracy does not need a division-size force to safeguard the incoming president in its capital." These developments underscore the deep democratic issues that have come to the forefront in recent weeks, as the nation grapples with the aftermath of the Capitol attack and the ongoing threats to the democratic process.

History in the Making: Biden Sworn In as Oldest President Amid COVID-19 and Political Divide

Joe Biden was sworn in as the 46th President of the United States on Wednesday, January 20, 2021, in a scaled-back ceremony at the Capitol, becoming the oldest president in US history at 78 years old. Amid heightened security concerns following the January 6 Capitol siege and the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic, Biden took the oath of office, vowing to preserve, protect, and defend the US Constitution.

Biden's swearing-in ceremony was steeped in history. He used a family heirloom Bible, owned by his great-great-grandfather, to take the oath. Biden pledged to "preserve, protect and defend the Constitution of the United States," and in his inaugural address, he emphasized unity, healing, and the need to address the crises facing the nation.

Donald Trump, the outgoing president, broke with tradition by not attending Biden's inauguration. Instead, he left Washington, D.C., earlier in the day, eschewing the peaceful transfer of power that has been a hallmark of US democracy. Top Republicans, former presidents Barack Obama, George W. Bush, and Bill Clinton attended the ceremony.

Kamala Harris made history as the first Black, first woman, and first Asian American vice president. During her swearing-in ceremony, she was sworn in by Associate Justice Sonia Sotomayor, the first Latina Supreme Court justice. Harris used two Bibles: one owned by Thurgood Marshall, the first Black Supreme Court justice, and another belonging to her late mother.

The inauguration took place amid increased security, with thousands of National Guard troops deployed around the Capitol and the National Mall. The Mall was filled with nearly 200,000 flags and 56 pillars of light representing each US state and territory. Despite the somber mood, there were moments of joy and optimism as Biden and Harris took the oaths of office.

This inauguration took place during a tumultuous time in American history. The US is grappling with a deep political divide, economic turmoil, and a devastating pandemic that has claimed over 400,000 lives. In his inaugural address, Biden acknowledged the challenges and offered a message of hope and unity.

Biden and Harris face significant challenges in their first days in office. They must work to unite a deeply divided nation, tackle the COVID-19 crisis, and address economic issues exacerbated by the pandemic. In his remarks, Biden emphasized the need for unity and called on Americans to come together.

As Biden and Harris take the reins of power, there is a renewed sense of hope and optimism for the future of the United States. The inauguration marked a new chapter in American history, one filled with challenges but also brimming with potential. The next four years will be critical in shaping the future of the US and the world.

Dignitaries Gather for Biden's Inauguration Amid COVID-19 Safety Measures and Political Divides

WASHINGTON – Joe Biden's inauguration as the 46th president of the United States unfolded on a chilly but sunny day Wednesday, with dignitaries, former presidents, lawmakers, and governors arriving at the Capitol to mark the peaceful transfer of power.

Former presidents Bill Clinton and George W. Bush, as well as current House Speaker Nancy Pelosi and Senate Majority Leader Chuck Schumer, were among the attendees. Former vice presidents Al Gore and Mike Pence also made an appearance.

As the U.S. Marine Band played, invited guests took their seats in widely spaced chairs, surrounded by security measures in place due to the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic.

Former President Barack Obama and South Carolina Rep. James Clyburn, a key figure in Biden's presidential campaign, were seen greeting each other warmly before taking their places on the platform.

Clyburn, who endorsed Biden early in the primary race, shared his thoughts on the significance of the day. "Today's a great day for our country," he told reporters. "We've come a long way since January 6th, and we're moving forward."

As congressional leaders and other notable figures took their places on the platform, former GOP senator Jeff Flake from Arizona spoke to the importance of the day's events. "The peaceful transfer of power is the bedrock of our democracy," he told USA TODAY. "It's a testament to the resilience of our country."

Donald Trump, the first departing commander-in-chief since 1869 to skip his successor's swearing-in, did not attend the ceremony. Instead, he released a prerecorded video statement earlier in the day.

Vice President Mike Pence was among the Republicans in attendance, along with former President George W. Bush and his wife, Laura. Former President Jimmy Carter was the only former president not participating in the ceremony.

As the ceremony progressed, Jennifer Lopez was set to perform, with actor Tom Hanks set to introduce her. Alex Rodriguez, Lopez's fiancé, was also spotted at the event.

Flake, who has been a vocal critic of Trump, emphasized the importance of unity moving forward. "We need to come together as a country," he said. "This is a new chapter, and it's important that we all support the new administration and work together for the betterment of our country."

"I felt honored to wear it."

Lady Gaga: "The Schiaparelli dress was just so beautiful and meaningful. I felt honored to wear it."

Daniel Roseberry (Creative Director, Maison Schiaparelli): "The Schiaparelli ensemble was a love letter to America, celebrating Lady Gaga's artistry and her Italian-American heritage."

Gaga's decision to wear Schiaparelli, an Italian designer, was a personal choice that reflected her Italian-American roots. Daniel Roseberry, the current creative director of Maison Schiaparelli, expressed his delight over the collaboration. "The Schiaparelli ensemble was a love letter to America, celebrating Lady Gaga's artistry and her Italian-American heritage," he said.

Lady Gaga: "I've always felt a deep connection to my Italian heritage, and wearing Schiaparelli at the inauguration was a way to honor that."

Before the inauguration ceremony, Lady Gaga wore a white cape by Givenchy, which fans compared to Princess Leia's iconic look. For her singing performance, she donned a fitted navy cashmere jacket and a voluminous washed red silk faille skirt. Her hair was styled in a braid, similar to the previous day, but accented with a red flower. Roseberry, who is American, further tied the French brand Schiaparelli back to the U.S. with his background.

Daniel Roseberry: "As an American, it's an honor to be a part of such a significant moment in American history, and to work with an iconic artist like Lady Gaga."

US Capitol Complex Locked Down During Inauguration Rehearsal Due to Nearby Fire

The US Capitol complex in Washington, DC, was temporarily locked down on Monday during a rehearsal for President-elect Joe Biden's inauguration due to security concerns raised by a fire in a homeless encampment about 1.6 kilometres away.

According to reports, the fire broke out near the intersection of Massachusetts Avenue and New Jersey Avenue, not far from the Capitol Grounds. The cause of the fire was not immediately clear, but smoke from the blaze was visible from the Capitol complex.

Officials stressed that there was no threat to the public or the inauguration from the fire. Acting Capitol Police Chief Yogananda Pittman ordered the evacuation and lockdown as a precautionary measure.

President-elect Biden was not present at the rehearsal during the lockdown. Instead, he spent the day at the Willard InterContinental Hotel in downtown Washington, DC, preparing for his inauguration ceremony.

Heightened security measures have been in place around the Capitol since the January 6 riot, when a mob of Trump supporters stormed the complex, leading to the deaths of five people and injuring over 140 police officers.

As a result, the area has been on high alert and lockdown, with National Guard troops and other law enforcement agencies stationed throughout the city.

Participants of the inauguration rehearsal, including a military band, were directed to move to a secure location inside the Capitol complex. The lockdown caused delays and disruptions to the rehearsal schedule.

The US Secret Service announced on Twitter that the lockdown was a precautionary measure, confirming there was no public threat. "There is no threat to public safety at this time," the agency tweeted.

Shane Fausey, the president of the Council of Prison Locals, which represents more than 33,000 employees of the federal prison system, told AP that the decision was made due to "the current volatile climate in our country."

"Our priority is the safety and security of our staff and the inmates in our care," Fausey said. "This lockdown is a necessary measure to ensure that."

No specific incidents within the facilities prompted the lockdown. However, coordination with the Justice Department for deploying as needed is ongoing, Long added.

Inmates were not informed of the lockdown until after they were already secured in their cells. According to the lockdown guidelines, inmates will have limited access to showers, phones, and email, and can participate in basic activities.

Aaron McGlothin, the local union president at the Federal Correctional Institution in Mendota, California, reported a potential case of tuberculosis at the facility. "We've been dealing with this COVID-19 situation and now this," McGlothin said. "It's just one thing after another."

The lockdown is the second nationwide lockdown in the federal prison system, following one in April 2020 due to the COVID-19 pandemic. Special Operations Response Teams are being relocated to Washington, D.C., to strengthen security around the inauguration.

"BOP continues to closely monitor the situation and will make adjustments as needed to ensure the continued safety and security of our staff and inmates," he said.

City of Philadelphia, a Catholic foster care agency argued that it should be exempted from placing children with same-sex couples based on religious grounds.

However, 303 Creative is unique in that it is not an actual refusal of service but rather a preemptive request for the right to deny services to same-sex couples. Kristen Waggoner, President of Alliance Defending Freedom, which represents 303 Creative, explained, "Lorie simply wants the freedom to express her beliefs through her creative work, without fear of government punishment."

The Supreme Court has opted to focus on the free speech argument, declining to take up the freedom of religion aspect or to reconsider the Smith v. Employment Division precedent. Waggoner argued, "Creative professionals, like Lorie, deserve the same protections afforded to other artists and speakers."

Dale Carpenter, a law professor at Southern Methodist University, and Eugene Volokh, a First Amendment legal scholar at the University of California, Los Angeles, have filed a friend-of-the-court brief in support of 303 Creative's First Amendment claims for expressive goods and services. Carpenter stated, "Artists and creators should have the freedom to choose which messages they wish to convey through their work."

Volokh added, "A ruling in favor of 303 Creative would not only protect the rights of designers like Lorie but also set a precedent for other creators and businesses."

However, critics, including Pizer, warn that a ruling in favor of 303 Creative could legitimize discrimination against LGBTQ individuals under the guise of free speech. "The Supreme Court must recognize that the First Amendment does not give businesses the right to discriminate against marginalized communities," she emphasized.

The U.S. Supreme Court has agreed to let the U.S. solicitor general present arguments on behalf of the Biden administration in this case. The solicitor general's role is to represent the interests of the federal government before the Supreme Court.

The outcome of 303 Creative v. Elenis remains uncertain, with both sides presenting compelling arguments. What is clear, however, is that this case will have far-reaching implications for the LGBTQ community and the broader issue of nondiscrimination in America.

Pizer concluded, "The Supreme Court has an opportunity to uphold the principle of nondiscrimination and send a message that all people, regardless of their sexual orientation or gender identity, deserve equal respect and dignity under the law."

Waggoner countered, "The Supreme Court also has an opportunity to uphold the First Amendment rights of creative professionals and ensure that they are not forced to express messages that violate their deeply held beliefs."

As the Supreme Court prepares to weigh in on this divisive issue, the eyes of the nation will be on the nine justices, who hold the power to shape the future of LGBTQ rights in America.

Capitol Riot: Police Command Structure Collapsed, Officers Unprepared, Report Says

WASHINGTON (AP) – The U.S. Capitol riot on January 6, 2021, left the police command structure in disarray, with officers forced to fend for themselves against a mob that was better armed and more organized than they had anticipated. A report released this week detailed the failures of communication, planning, and leadership that contributed to the breach of the Capitol building and the resulting chaos.

The report, compiled by the Senate Homeland Security and Governmental Affairs Committee, revealed that Capitol Police Chief Steven Sund and other top officials were inadequately warned about the scale of the threat from the rioters. Sund resigned following the incident, and it was later reported that he was with Vice President Mike Pence during the event and uncommunicative.

Interim Capitol Police Chief Yogananda Pittman and Lt. Tarik Johnson provided limited instructions to the officers on the ground, further complicating the response to the mob. The Capitol Police lacked an adequate preparation and briefing process for the January 6 event, unlike for other major events, the report found. The department had not conducted a threat assessment or developed contingency plans for a large-scale breach of the Capitol complex.

Moreover, most rioters left the scene without being arrested due to the overwhelming number of rioters compared to the number of police officers present. The Metropolitan Police Department (MPD), which provides support to the Capitol Police, was also understaffed and lacked the resources to effectively respond to the situation.

The report also revealed that some Capitol Police officers were not provided with proper equipment, such as riot gear and protective helmets. This further hindered their ability to effectively respond to the rioters.

In the aftermath of the incident, the Capitol Police have faced criticism for their lack of preparedness and their response to the riot. Many have called for reforms and increased funding for the department to prevent similar incidents from happening in the future.

The January 6 Capitol riot was a pivotal moment in American history, and the events that unfolded that day have left a lasting impact on the country. The report released this week provides a detailed account of the failures that contributed to the breach of the Capitol building and the resulting chaos.

As the investigations into the incident continue, it is crucial that the necessary steps are taken to ensure the security of the Capitol and the safety of those who work and visit there.

In conclusion, the Capitol riot on January 6, 2021, exposed significant failures in the Capitol Police command structure, preparation, and communication. ECB Joins Global Central Banks in Asset Purchase Tapering: "A Recalibration, Not a Taper" - Christine Lagarde

The European Central Bank (ECB) announced on Thursday that it will begin reducing the pace of its asset purchases under its Pandemic Emergency Purchase Program (PEPP), marking a significant step towards exiting the era of quantitative easing (QE) in Europe.

Christine Lagarde, President of the ECB, confirmed the decision in a press conference, stating, "The Governing Council has decided to recalibrate the pace of net asset purchases under the pandemic emergency purchase programme (PEPP) at a moderately lower pace than in the previous months."

The ECB's asset purchase rate has been significantly higher than that of the Federal Reserve, reaching an average of €150 billion ($181 billion) per month since the onset of the pandemic. This compares to the Federal Reserve's current monthly expansion of $120 billion.

Lagarde emphasized that the decision to reduce asset purchases is a 'recalibration' rather than tapering, echoing similar stances taken by other major central banks, such as the Bank of Japan, Bank of Canada, Bank of England, Reserve Bank of New Zealand, and Reserve Bank of Australia, which have already started tapering or ending their QE programs.

The PEPP will see a 'moderately lower' pace of net asset purchases, continuing at least until March 2022, with a balance level maintained at least until the end of 2023. Other ECB programs, including the Targeted Longer-Term Refinancing Operations (TLTRO III) and the Asset Purchase Program (APP), will continue as planned.

Lagarde explained, "The Governing Council continues to stand ready to adjust all of its instruments, as appropriate, to ensure that inflation remains on a sustained adjustment path towards its 2% medium-term target."

The ECB's total asset balance has reached approximately €8.2 trillion, with a major portion in bonds and loans to banks. Central banks globally agree that QE programs need to end before interest rates can be hiked to avoid disrupting the yield curve.

Despite the consensus on the need to start tapering among major central banks, the Federal Reserve is still expanding its balance sheet by $120 billion a month.

Lagarde reaffirmed the unanimous decision to recalibrate asset purchases amidst efforts to navigate exiting QE without destabilizing the Eurozone economy. She emphasized that the ECB's main priority remains maintaining price stability in the Eurozone, adding, "Our monetary policy stance will remain accommodative for a prolonged period of time."

Donald Rumsfeld, Former U.S. Secretary of Defense and Architect of Post-9/11 Wars, Dies at 88

Donald Rumsfeld, the former U.S. Secretary of Defense who oversaw the military campaigns in Afghanistan and Iraq following the September 11 attacks, passed away on June 29, 2021, at the age of 88 due to complications from multiple myeloma.

Rumsfeld's career spanned over five decades, marked by his two tenures as U.S. Secretary of Defense, first under President Gerald Ford from 1975 to 1977 and then under President George W. Bush from 2001 to 2006. His most prominent role came during the Bush administration, where he managed the Middle East wars and implemented controversial policies and strategies.

President Bush remembered Rumsfeld for his service and dedication following the attacks on September 11, 2001, stating, "Donald Rumsfeld was a strong and capable leader who served our country with distinction as Secretary of Defense during times of war and times of peace."

Rumsfeld's involvement in post-9/11 military conflicts was contentious, with criticisms surrounding the search for weapons of mass destruction in Iraq and reports of detainee abuses at places like Abu Ghraib prison.

Despite the later admissions of faulty intelligence, Rumsfeld maintained that removing Saddam Hussein from power in Iraq was justified. He argued, "Saddam Hussein was a threat. He had used weapons of mass destruction against his own people. He had invaded a neighboring country. He had defied 17 UN resolutions. He had a history of aggression against his neighbors and against us."

Errol Morris, a documentarian who spent 33 hours interviewing Rumsfeld for his film "The Fog of War," described him as somewhat 'clueless,' stating, "He just doesn't know what's going on. He has no idea why things are the way they are."

Rumsfeld, after leaving politics, focused on various projects. He wrote a memoir titled "Known and Unknown: A Memoir," participated in Morris' documentary, and launched a mobile game called "Strategic Command: WWII – Pacific."

Reflecting on Rumsfeld's death, the Rumsfeld family released a statement highlighting his love for his wife, family, friends, and his dedication to public service. They stated, "His loss is deeply felt by those who knew him best and who rejoice in the exceptional life he lived and the legacy of good he leaves behind."

Rumsfeld's legacy will be remembered for his influence on U.S. foreign policy during a pivotal time in history. Although his decisions and actions were often met with criticism and controversy, Rumsfeld's impact on the political landscape is undeniable.

As President Bush concluded, "Donald Rumsfeld was a patriot who served his country with distinction, and he will be deeply missed."

Mare of Easttown's Unexpected Twist: The Poignant Demise of Detective Colin Zabel, as Revealed by Evan Peters, Craig Zobel, and Brad Ingelsby

Fact Check: Former President Bill Clinton Was Not Poisoned to Death at Guantanamo Bay, Contrary to False Social Media Claims

In a bizarre turn of events, a false claim has circulated on social media platforms, alleging that former President Bill Clinton was poisoned to death at Guantanamo Bay. The unfounded rumor gained traction amidst a broader wave of fabricated stories about high-profile figures, often linked to the baseless QAnon conspiracy theory.

For the record, Bill Clinton was not in Guantanamo Bay; instead, he had been hospitalized in California for a non-COVID-related infection. Angel Ureña, a spokesperson for the former president, confirmed Clinton's health was improving, and he was in excellent spirits. Ureña stated, "President Clinton was admitted to Southern California Hospital for the treatment of a non-COVID-related infection. He is on the mend, in good spirits, and is looking forward to getting back to work."

The false claim originated from Real Raw News, a website known for publishing fake stories and conspiracy theories. While the site boasts a disclaimer stating its content contains humor, parody, and satire, this disclaimer is hidden on the about page. Michael Ruffin, who uses the pseudonym Michael Baxter on the site, defends the accuracy of his stories, despite the satire disclaimer.

Real Raw News falsely reported Clinton's death, attributing the information to an unnamed source at Guantanamo Bay and fictitious involvement of a U.S. Naval Hospital officer. Dawn Grimes, the spokeswoman for the U.S. Naval Hospital in Guantanamo Bay, refuted these claims, stating, "There is no truth to the rumor that former President Bill Clinton died at the hospital. President Clinton was never a patient here."

Grimes continued, "There has been no autopsy performed or overseen by Capt. Dale Ramirez or any other member of our staff regarding former President Clinton. We are focused on the health and well-being of the service members and their families who are under our care."

Rumors of high-profile figures' deaths or ill health are not new, but the recent surge in such stories can be attributed to the QAnon conspiracy theory. The baseless theory claims that a cabal of Satan-worshipping pedophiles is running a global child sex trafficking ring and that various public figures, including politicians and celebrities, are part of this nefarious plot.

The QAnon conspiracy theory originated in 2017 on the 4chan message board and has since gained a massive following, with adherents posting their beliefs on social media platforms and in real-life gatherings. The theory has been denounced by law enforcement agencies and fact-checking organizations for its lack of evidence and potential to incite violence.

Despite the overwhelming evidence debunking the QAnon conspiracy theory, its followers continue to spread false rumors about various public figures, including former presidents. In the past, they have falsely claimed that President Barack Obama was a secret Muslim, that Hillary Clinton was involved in a child trafficking ring, and that former President George H.W. Bush was a Satanist.

The false claim about Bill Clinton's death at Guantanamo Bay is just the latest in a long line of fabricated stories about the former president. In 2016, a false rumor circulated that Clinton had Parkinson's disease. In 2017, another false story claimed that Clinton had been hospitalized for a stroke. And in 2018, a false report stated that Clinton had been arrested for sex crimes.

These false rumors often gain traction on social media platforms, fueled by the anonymity and lack of fact-checking that exists on these sites. The spread of these false stories can have serious consequences, including damaging the reputations of public figures and inciting violence.

It is essential to fact-check information before sharing it on social media or believing it to be true. Reputable fact-checking organizations, such as PolitiFact and Snopes, can help verify the accuracy of information.

PolitiFact conducted a fact-check on the false claim about Bill Clinton's death at Guantanamo Bay and found it to be "Pants on Fire," meaning it contained no truth whatsoever.

The proliferation of false rumors about public figures is a growing concern in today's digital age. Social media platforms must take responsibility for fact-checking the information that is shared on their sites and removing false or misleading content.

Individuals must also take responsibility for fact-checking the information they consume and share. By doing so, we can help prevent the spread of false rumors and misinformation.

The false claim about Bill Clinton's death at Guantanamo Bay serves as a reminder of the importance of fact-checking and the potential harm that false rumors can cause.

Donald Rumsfeld, Architect of Iraq War and Former U.S. Defense Secretary, Dies at 88

June 30 – Former U.S. Defense Secretary Donald Rumsfeld, a key figure in the Iraq War and architect of military strategy during his tenure under Presidents Gerald Ford and George W. Bush, passed away on Tuesday at the age of 88.

Rumsfeld served as Defense Secretary twice – first from 1975 to 1977 under Ford and later from 2001 to 2006 under Bush. His second term was marked by the controversial invasion of Iraq, which took place in March 2003.

At the time, Rumsfeld justified the invasion by claiming Iraq possessed weapons of mass destruction (WMDs), which were later found to be non-existent. This revelation, along with other controversial decisions made during his tenure, led to significant international and domestic controversy.

One of the most infamous episodes during Rumsfeld's tenure was the Abu Ghraib prisoner abuse scandal, which came to light in 2004. The scandal involved the physical and sexual abuse of detainees held at the Abu Ghraib prison in Iraq, leading to widespread international condemnation.

Rumsfeld also authorized harsh interrogation techniques for detainees at Guantánamo Bay and other facilities, drawing further criticism from human rights organizations and foreign governments.

Despite his close alliance with Vice President Dick Cheney, Rumsfeld faced intense criticism for his handling of the Iraq war. President Bush replaced Rumsfeld in November 2006, citing diminishing support for the conflict.

Critics argue that Rumsfeld's strategic errors in Iraq and Afghanistan contributed to the protracted nature of these conflicts. His management style and decisions were also blamed for the instability and violence in post-invasion Iraq.

Beyond his government roles, Rumsfeld was a successful businessman, serving in various capacities including as a Navy pilot and U.S. NATO ambassador. He was born on June 9, 1932, in Evanston, Illinois, and graduated from Princeton University in 1954.

Rumsfeld began his political career in the 1960s, serving as a congressional liaison for the Department of Defense under President Lyndon B. Johnson. He went on to become a member of the U.S. House of Representatives from Illinois from 1963 to 1969.

Rumsfeld's military career began in 1957 when he joined the U.S. Navy and became a fighter pilot. He flew 130 combat missions during the Vietnam War and was awarded the Distinguished Flying Cross.

In the 1990s, Rumsfeld served as the U.S. Ambassador to NATO. He was also the chief executive officer of General Instrument Corporation from 1990 to 1993 and served on the board of directors of several other companies.

Despite his controversial tenure as Defense Secretary, Rumsfeld will be remembered for his significant contributions to U.S. politics and military strategy. He is survived by his wife, Joyce, and their four children.

Maj. Colin Powell's Unyielding Courage: A Vietnam War Hero's Selfless Acts

As the flames consumed the helicopter, Powell tore away burning metal with his bare hands to free a trapped passenger. His selfless actions that day would go down in military history, earning him the Soldier's Medal for heroism.

The Soldier's Medal, established in 1926, is the United States military's highest decoration for acts of heroism not involving conflict with an enemy. Powell's actions during the helicopter crash exemplified the award's purpose.

WASHINGTON (AP) – The Justice Department announced Thursday it has recovered most of the ransom paid to hackers who attacked Colonial Pipeline, marking the first major operation by a new task force created by the Biden administration to combat ransomware attacks.

FBI Deputy Director Paul Abbate said the FBI was able to identify and seize 63.7 bitcoins, now valued at $2.3 million, from the hackers. That amounted to 85% of the total ransom paid.

"We understand that ransomware attacks can have significant consequences on critical infrastructure, and that's why we're using all the tools at our disposal to disrupt these criminal actors," Abbate said.

Colonial Pipeline President and Chief Executive Joseph Blount called the operation a "significant milestone."

"Our goal was to disrupt their business model, hold them accountable for their criminal attack, and prevent them from profiting from their attack on Colonial Pipeline," Blount said.

Acting U.S. Attorney Stephanie Hinds for the Northern District of California, where the seizure was made, praised the collaboration between law enforcement and the private sector.

"The private sector plays a critical role in cybersecurity, and the Justice Department is committed to working with companies to identify, disrupt, and prosecute cybercriminals," Hinds said.

Ballod noted, "Zero-day exploits give attackers a significant advantage, as they can bypass security measures that rely on known vulnerabilities."

Once inside a target's network, DarkSide moved swiftly to encrypt files and exfiltrate data. They also investigated victims' cyber insurance policies to tailor ransom demands effectively. Wittmann commented, "DarkSide's understanding of cyber insurance policies is a testament to their research capabilities and knowledge of the cyber threat landscape."

DarkSide's quick attack window and demands on the high end, typically $5 million or more, put pressure on organizations to respond rapidly. Ballod cautioned, "The window of opportunity for organizations to prevent a ransomware attack is shrinking, making it essential for them to invest in robust cybersecurity measures and incident response plans."

DarkSide threatened to share stolen information with short-sellers if publicly traded companies refused to pay the ransom. Wittmann warned, "The potential for public disclosure of sensitive information can lead to significant reputational damage and financial losses for organizations."

After DarkSide's shutdown by law enforcement, affiliates complained on a forum that they had not been paid their share of the ransoms. Walshe Jr. commented, "The lack of transparency in ransomware-as-a-service operations can lead to mistrust among affiliates and potential legal repercussions."

Seven of Tantleff's clients paid ransoms ranging from $1.25 million to $6 million after negotiations from higher initial demands. This incident is part of a growing wave of ransomware attacks targeting businesses, governments, and other entities globally. More than half of the victims end up paying a ransom, with the average ransom paid last year estimated at about $312,000, according to Michael Daniel, President and CEO of the Cyber Threat Alliance.

"Ransomware attacks are becoming increasingly common and sophisticated," Daniel said. "Cybercriminals are using more aggressive tactics, threatening to release sensitive data if the ransom isn't paid."

The Colonial Pipeline attack in May, which disrupted fuel supplies to the East Coast, highlighted ransomware's potential threat to national security and the economy. The attack was carried out by the DarkSide ransomware group, which announced it was shutting down after losing control of its servers. However, some security experts suspect it might be an exit scam.

"Ransomware attacks are a serious threat, and they're only going to get worse," said Austin Berglas, Former Head of Cyber Branch, FBI's New York Field Office, and Now Global Head of Professional Services, BlueVoyant. "Cybercriminals are constantly evolving their tactics, and they're using more sophisticated techniques to evade detection and extort larger ransoms."

The use of cryptocurrencies like Bitcoin has facilitated the growth of ransomware by enabling untraceable transactions. In 2020, nearly 2,400 U.S. health care facilities, schools, and governments were hit by ransomware, with victims paying an estimated $400 million in ransoms, according to the Ransomware Task Force.

"Ransomware attacks are a significant threat to businesses and organizations of all sizes," Daniel said. "They can cause significant financial damage, disrupt operations, and damage reputations. And unfortunately, once you're hit, there's no guarantee you'll get your data back, even if you pay the ransom."

Companies specializing in ransomware attack negotiations have emerged, indicating the unique challenges and decisions victims face. "Negotiating with cybercriminals can be a complex and high-stakes process," Berglas said. "Victims need to understand the risks and potential outcomes, and they need to be prepared to make tough decisions."

The FBI and other law enforcement agencies are working to disrupt ransomware attacks and bring the perpetrators to justice. However, the global nature of the threat and the use of cryptocurrencies make it a challenging problem to solve.

"Ransomware attacks are a serious threat to national security and the economy," Daniel said. "Governments and businesses need to work together to disrupt these attacks and hold the perpetrators accountable. And individuals and organizations need to take steps to protect themselves, including implementing strong cybersecurity measures and backing up their data regularly."

Berglas added, "Ransomware attacks are a complex problem that requires a multi-faceted solution. We all have a role to play in preventing and responding to these attacks."

As the threat of ransomware continues to grow, experts warn that individuals and organizations need to be vigilant and take steps to protect themselves. This includes implementing strong cybersecurity measures, backing up data regularly, and being aware of the latest threats and tactics used by cybercriminals.

"Ransomware attacks are a serious threat, and they're only going to get worse," Berglas said. "But with the right preparation and response, we can minimize the damage and protect ourselves from these attacks."

Fact Check: Colonial Pipeline Hack and Election Fraud Claims - Two Different Things

The recent cyberattack on the Colonial Pipeline has sparked a wave of comparisons to unfounded claims of election fraud during the November 2020 elections. Social media users suggest that if one can be hacked, so can the other. However, a fact check reveals these claims are misleading.

On May 7, 2021, the Colonial Pipeline was hit by a ransomware attack, affecting its IT systems and halting operations. Kevin Feeney, a spokesperson for Colonial Pipeline, stated, "We took certain systems offline to contain the threat, which temporarily halted all pipeline operations. We engaged a leading, third-party cybersecurity firm to help us understand the nature of what happened."

In contrast, investigations have found no evidence of interference in the November 2020 election. Will Adler, a senior technologist for elections and democracy at the Center for Democracy & Technology, commented, "The comparison between the Colonial Pipeline hack and election fraud claims is misleading. U.S. voting systems are not vulnerable on a large scale."

Ransomware attacks, like the one on Colonial Pipeline, encrypt data to extort ransom. They often target corporations and hospitals. The FBI identified software from the cybercrime group DarkSide as responsible for the Colonial Pipeline attack.

Feeney further highlighted Colonial Pipeline's stringent IT and operational technology segmentation policies, stating, "Our IT systems are separate from our operational technology systems. The operational technology network that runs our pipelines is not connected to our corporate IT network. We have strict access controls for our operational technology network, and this attack did not impact our ability to safely operate, maintain the pipeline, or process transactions."

Posts connecting the pipeline hack to voting machine vulnerabilities build on baseless 2020 election fraud claims. However, the decentralized nature of U.S. elections and their security measures prevent such cyberattacks from impacting election outcomes.

Dominion Voting Systems and other authorities have consistently refuted claims of election infrastructure hacking in the 2020 election. In a statement, Dominion Voting Systems said, "There is no credible evidence to support these claims. Dominion systems were not involved in any way in the transfer of votes from one candidate to another, nor was any vote count or election result altered or manipulated."

Adler reiterated, "There is no evidence to suggest that U.S. voting systems were targeted or compromised in a way that could have changed the outcome of the 2020 election. It's important to separate these two issues, as they are fundamentally different."

Colonial Pipeline's Feeney added, "Our focus right now is on restoring full pipeline operations and making our system more secure for the future. It's crucial that we don't conflate these two distinct issues."

In conclusion, the Colonial Pipeline hack and election fraud claims are two unrelated matters. While the pipeline was affected by a ransomware attack, U.S. voting systems remain secure and resilient. As Adler stated, "The comparison between the two is misleading, and it's essential to maintain an accurate understanding of each issue."

D.C. Police Department's Computer Network Breached by Hackers Babuk, Hundreds of Internal Documents Released

Hackers known as Babuk have infiltrated the computer network of the Metropolitan Police Department (MPD) in Washington D.C., resulting in the release of hundreds of sensitive internal documents. The documents, which include daily intelligence briefing papers of Police Chief Robert J. Contee III and information on street crews and threats following the January 6 Capitol attack, were made public on the dark web.

In a statement posted on their website, Babuk claimed responsibility for the cyberattack and threatened to release more data unless District officials paid a ransom. However, following a breakdown in negotiations, the group announced they had already posted all stolen files and shared their hacking tool with other cybercriminal groups.

"This is a serious breach of the trust that the community has placed in the Metropolitan Police Department," said Greggory Pemberton, Chairman of the D.C. Police Union. "The fact that sensitive information, including that of gang suspects and witnesses to crimes, has been released to the public is unacceptable."

Robert J. Contee III, Chief of the D.C. Police, confirmed that the department had experienced a cyberattack but refused to comment on ongoing negotiations or the authenticity of the leaked documents. "We are taking all necessary steps to secure our systems and protect the privacy of our employees and the community we serve," Contee said in a statement.

Raj Samani, Chief Scientist and Cybersecurity Fellow at McAfee Corp., cautioned against paying ransoms to cybercriminals, explaining that it doesn't guarantee safety from further demands or the sale of stolen data on the dark web. "Paying the ransom can embolden these groups and fund their future attacks," Samani warned.

The stolen files, which range from a job applicant's resume to lists of gang suspects and witnesses to crimes, were made public on the dark web earlier this week. Affected individuals have been contacted by the police department and offered guidance, according to Contee.

The release of gang files poses a significant danger, potentially exposing suspects not under arrest, witnesses, and details on gang territories. Pemberton called for an inspector general investigation into the breach and the department's handling of sensitive information.

Babuk, a relatively new cybercriminal group, has gained notoriety for targeting high-profile organizations, including schools, hospitals, and government agencies. In a statement on their website, they claimed to have used a zero-day exploit to gain access to the MPD's network.

Zero-day exploits are vulnerabilities in software that are unknown to the software vendor, leaving no patch or defense against the attack. These exploits are highly valued by cybercriminals and can be sold for significant sums on the dark web.

The MPD is not the first government agency to be targeted by Babuk. In May, the group claimed responsibility for hacking the computer network of the Saskatchewan Health Authority in Canada, demanding a $1 million ransom.

The cyberattack on the MPD is a stark reminder of the increasing threat posed by cybercriminals to government agencies and other high-profile organizations. According to a recent report by Cybersecurity Ventures, the global cost of cybercrime is expected to reach $10.5 trillion annually by 2025.

In response to the cyberattack, District officials have closed off Babuk's entry point into the MPD's network and are working to identify the extent of the damage. The FBI is also investigating the attack and is offering a reward of up to $250,000 for information leading to the identification, arrest, and conviction of the individuals responsible.

As the investigation into the cyberattack continues, District officials are urging residents and businesses to remain vigilant and to report any suspicious activity to the police department or the FBI. They are also encouraging everyone to take basic cybersecurity precautions, such as using strong passwords and keeping software up to date.

The cyberattack on the MPD serves as a reminder that no organization is immune to the threat of cybercrime. As technology continues to evolve, so too will the tactics used by cybercriminals. It is essential that individuals and organizations remain vigilant and take proactive steps to protect themselves from these threats. "We cannot afford to be complacent when it comes to cybersecurity," Pemberton said. "We must do everything in our power to prevent these attacks and to minimize the damage when they do occur."

Fact Check: House GOP Falsely Blames Biden for Gas, Lumber Price Hikes

WASHINGTON (AP) – House Republican Leader Kevin McCarthy, R-Calif., and other top Republicans have repeatedly blamed President Joe Biden for the recent surge in gasoline and lumber prices, but the facts tell a different story.

McCarthy, in a tweet, claimed that the "Biden administration's energy policies are causing pain at the pump and in your wallet." Liz Cheney, R-Wyo., the No. 3 House Republican, echoed similar sentiments, stating, "President Biden's policies have led to a 400% increase in lumber prices."

Ronna McDaniel, head of the Republican National Committee, chimed in, tweeting that "Joe Biden's anti-energy policies are hurting American families."

But experts say the recent increase in gas prices is not due to Biden's policies but rather the cyberattack on the Colonial Pipeline, which disrupted fuel supplies in the Southeast.

Patrick DeHaan, head of petroleum analysis at GasBuddy, explained that "the Colonial Pipeline cyberattack caused supply disruptions that led to panic buying and price spikes."

The increase in gas prices is not the only sector experiencing price hikes. The difficulties of restarting the U.S. and global economies post-pandemic have caused shortages and price increases in various sectors.

McCarthy's and Cheney's claims connecting Biden's actions on the Keystone XL pipeline to the current gasoline prices are misleading. The pipeline carries crude oil, not gasoline, and its cancellation did not directly impact gas prices.

DeHaan further clarified that "gas prices are higher because of a rapid bounce-back in demand and lingering problems from the Colonial Pipeline shutdown."

Comparing current gas prices to last year's prices is also misleading. Prices plummeted in 2020 due to the coronavirus pandemic, not because of Trump administration policies.

Despite the pipeline being back in operation, some states are experiencing gas shortages since the cyberattack. The shortages are due to distribution issues, not Biden's policies.

Lumber prices have surged due to increased demand and a sharp economic rebound, not Biden's policies. McDaniel's claim of a 400% increase is unfounded.

The Consumer Price Index, which measures price changes for goods and services, shows that lumber prices are up 237.3% from a year ago, not 400%. Moreover, the surge in lumber prices is a positive sign for the economy as it shows strong consumer demand for goods.

Cheney's statement also overlooks the fact that lumber prices began to rise before Biden took office. According to the National Association of Home Builders, lumber prices started to climb in late 2019, long before Biden's policies were implemented.

McCarthy, Cheney, and McDaniel's claims that Biden's policies are responsible for the recent surge in gas and lumber prices are unfounded and misleading. The facts show that the Colonial Pipeline cyberattack and the economic rebound are the primary causes of the price hikes.

FDA Expands COVID-19 Vaccine Booster Authorizations: Moderna, Janssen, and Pfizer-BioNTech, Including 'Mix and Match' Approach

The U.S. Food and Drug Administration (FDA) today expanded the emergency use authorizations (EUAs) for booster doses of the Moderna, Janssen (Johnson & Johnson), and Pfizer-BioNTech COVID-19 vaccines to eligible populations. Acting FDA Commissioner Janet Woodcock, M.D., and Peter Marks, M.D., Ph.D., Director of the FDA's Center for Biologics Evaluation and Research, issued the following statements:

"Today, the FDA is authorizing booster doses of Moderna, Janssen, and Pfizer-BioNTech COVID-19 vaccines for eligible populations. This decision is based on the available scientific data and the expertise of our scientific teams. As the pandemic continues to evolve, the FDA remains committed to facilitating the timely availability of safe and effective vaccines," said Acting FDA Commissioner Janet Woodcock, M.D.

"Our scientific and medical teams have carefully assessed the data on the safety and efficacy of booster doses for the Moderna, Janssen, and Pfizer-BioNTech COVID-19 vaccines. The available data support expanding the EUAs to include booster doses for certain populations," said Peter Marks, M.D., Ph.D., Director of the FDA's Center for Biologics Evaluation and Research.

Moderna Booster Dose Authorization

The FDA has authorized Moderna's booster dose for individuals 65 years and older and those 18-64 years old who are at high risk of severe COVID-19, have frequent institutional or occupational exposure to SARS-CoV-2, or are members of an Indigenous or racially or ethnically diverse population based on clinical trial data. The booster dose should be administered at least six months after completion of the primary series.

Janssen Booster Dose Authorization

The FDA has authorized a booster dose of the Janssen COVID-19 vaccine for individuals 18 years and older, at least two months after the initial dose. The Janssen booster dose has been shown to significantly increase antibody responses against SARS-CoV-2 in clinical trials.

Pfizer-BioNTech Booster Dose Clarification

The FDA has clarified that the Pfizer-BioNTech COVID-19 vaccine booster dose is authorized for individuals 18-64 years old who have frequent institutional or occupational exposure to SARS-CoV-2. The booster dose should be administered at least six months after completion of the primary series.

'Mix and Match' Booster Approach

The FDA has also authorized the use of 'mix and match' booster doses for all available COVID-19 vaccines. Eligibility and dosing intervals for the 'mix and match' boosters align with those for the vaccines used in primary vaccination.

Safety and Immunity Response Data

The FDA's authorization of booster doses for Moderna, Janssen, and Pfizer-BioNTech COVID-19 vaccines is based on safety and immunity response data from clinical trials. The trials demonstrated that booster doses significantly increased the immune response against SARS-CoV-2.

Side Effects

The side effects for booster doses of Moderna, Janssen, and Pfizer-BioNTech COVID-19 vaccines are generally similar to those experienced after the primary doses. The most common side effects include pain, redness, and swelling at the injection site, as well as fever, fatigue, and headache.

Myocarditis and Pericarditis Risks

The FDA and the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) have identified increased risks of myocarditis and pericarditis, as well as other conditions, linked to COVID-19 vaccines. However, both agencies affirm the overall safety and benefits of the vaccines.

Health Care Providers and CDC Recommendations

Health care providers are encouraged to follow CDC recommendations on booster administrations. The CDC will provide updated guidance on eligibility and dosing intervals for booster doses of Moderna, Janssen, and Pfizer-BioNTech COVID-19 vaccines.

We cannot afford to leave anyone behind in our efforts to end this pandemic, and I am committed to ensuring that every American has access to the resources and care they need.

In conclusion, I want to reiterate my commitment to ending this pandemic and to working with you, the American people, to build a better, stronger, and more resilient nation. Biden Administration Announces Sweeping Vaccine Mandates: OSHA's ETS, Federal Contractors, and Health Care Workers

In a bold move to curb the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic, President Joe Biden announced on September 9, 2021, a series of vaccine mandates aimed at large employers, federal contractors, and federal workers. The announcements mark the most comprehensive effort by the federal government to increase vaccination rates and contain the spread of the virus.

OSHA, the Occupational Safety and Health Administration, will develop an Emergency Temporary Standard (ETS) requiring employers with 100 or more employees to ensure their workforce is fully vaccinated against COVID-19 or undergo weekly testing for the virus. This mandate is expected to impact approximately 80 million workers in the United States.

Under the ETS, employers must provide paid time off for their employees to get vaccinated and recover from any side effects. OSHA's new rule is anticipated to have an immediate effect upon publication, bypassing the traditional notice-and-comment process.

Legal challenges to the ETS are imminent, particularly concerning the rule's wage-payment requirement and coverage of workers who recently recovered from COVID-19. Some critics argue that employers should not be required to pay for vaccine-related time off, as it goes beyond OSHA's scope.

President Biden also issued executive orders mandating vaccinations for employees of federal contractors and all federal workers, with minimal exceptions. Federal contractors must comply with the vaccine mandates as detailed by the Safer Federal Workforce Task Force by September 24, 2021.

Legal challenges to the federal contractor executive order may test presidential authority under the Procurement Act. Critics argue that the president does not have the power to mandate vaccines for contractor employees, as it goes beyond the scope of federal procurement regulations.

All federal executive branch workers are required to be vaccinated, with only legally required exceptions permitted. This mandate covers approximately 3.5 million employees in the federal workforce. The mandate will be enforced by the Safer Federal Workforce Task Force and may be subject to legal challenges.

The Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services (CMS) will require COVID-19 vaccinations for workers in most health care settings that receive Medicare or Medicaid reimbursement. This mandate is expected to impact approximately 17 million health care workers. Legal challenges to the CMS mandate may focus on religious and medical exemptions.

Biden Announces Sweeping Vaccine Mandates Affecting Up to 100 Million Americans

WASHINGTON (AP) – President Joe Biden on Thursday announced sweeping new vaccine mandates affecting up to 100 million Americans in an effort to combat the spread of the COVID-19 delta variant. The mandates apply to private-sector employees, health care workers, federal contractors, and others.

"We've been patient, but our patience is wearing thin. And your refusal has cost all of us," Biden said during a speech at the White House, criticizing unvaccinated Americans. "So, please, do the right thing – get vaccinated."

Republican leaders and some union chiefs quickly accused Biden of overstepping his authority and violating constitutional rights. Gov. Henry McMaster of South Carolina was among the critics.

"Joe Biden's unconstitutional actions threatening to shut down businesses or impose fines and penalties on South Carolinians will not be tolerated," McMaster said in a statement. "The people of South Carolina will not allow Joe Biden to infringe upon their livelihoods, their personal freedoms, or their children's education."
