The American Medical Association, the National Association of Manufacturers, and the Business Roundtable expressed support for Biden's efforts to increase vaccination rates. Everett Kelley, National President of the American Federation of Government Employees, also voiced his approval.

"We applaud President Biden's commitment to protecting the health and safety of federal employees," Kelley said in a statement. "These actions are necessary to prevent the spread of COVID-19 in the federal workforce and ensure a safe workplace for all."

New rules require employers with more than 100 workers to mandate vaccines or weekly testing, affecting about 80 million Americans. Employees of the executive branch and contractors with the federal government must be vaccinated, with no testing option, affecting several million more workers.

Biden's address also included efforts to increase virus testing, support for safe school operations, and urging large venues to require vaccinations or negative tests for entry. The new requirements will be enforced through various federal agencies, with specific penalties and guidelines for non-compliance.

Jen Psaki, White House Press Secretary, defended the president's actions during a press briefing.

"The president is using every tool at his disposal to save lives," Psaki said. "He believes that requiring vaccinations for employers with over 100 employees is a common-sense step to protect workers, their families, and the community."

Psaki added that the administration would work with businesses and organizations to ensure a smooth implementation of the new mandates.

The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) reported that more than 171 million Americans, or about 52% of the population, have been fully vaccinated against COVID-19. The CDC also reported that the seven-day average of daily new COVID-19 cases in the U.S. has increased by nearly 50% over the past two weeks.

The delta variant, first identified in India, now accounts for more than 99% of all sequenced COVID-19 cases in the U.S., according to the CDC. The delta variant is more contagious than previous strains and can cause more severe illness, particularly among unvaccinated individuals.

Biden urged Americans to get vaccinated to protect themselves, their loved ones, and their communities.

"We're going to protect the vast majority of Americans who have done the right thing and gotten vaccinated," Biden said. "But we're also going to require the other 80 million Americans who haven't gotten vaccinated to do the right thing."

Rare COVID-19 Breakthrough Cases Among the Fully Vaccinated: A Look at State-Level Data

The COVID-19 vaccines have proven to be highly effective in preventing severe disease, hospitalizations, and deaths. However, even among the fully vaccinated population, breakthrough cases still occur. These cases, where individuals test positive for COVID-19 despite being fully vaccinated, have raised concerns and questions about the vaccines' efficacy and the need for continued precautions.

The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) tracks hospitalizations and deaths among the fully vaccinated population, but not all breakthrough infections are reported in their data. To better understand the frequency and implications of COVID-19 breakthrough cases, we reviewed data on breakthrough cases, hospitalizations, and deaths from official state sources for all 50 states and the District of Columbia.

It is important to note that not all hospitalizations and deaths in fully vaccinated individuals are directly attributable to COVID-19. Some may have tested positive for the virus but had other underlying health conditions or causes of death. Therefore, it is crucial to interpret state-level data with this context in mind.

Half of the states in the U.S. report data on COVID-19 breakthrough events, but the frequency and detail of reporting vary significantly. Some states, such as California and New York, provide extensive information on the number of breakthrough cases, hospitalizations, and deaths, while others, like Alabama and Mississippi, do not report any data at all.

Despite the variability in reporting, the available data indicates that breakthrough cases, hospitalizations, and deaths among the fully vaccinated are extremely rare. Across all reporting states, the rates of breakthrough cases are below 1%. For instance, California reported 3,353 breakthrough cases out of over 12 million fully vaccinated individuals, representing a rate of 0.027%.

Furthermore, more than 90% of COVID-19 cases, hospitalizations, and deaths occur among unvaccinated or not fully vaccinated individuals. According to the CDC, as of August 2021, unvaccinated individuals were 14 times more likely to be hospitalized due to COVID-19 and 17 times more likely to die from the virus than those who were fully vaccinated.

State-level data supports the effectiveness of COVID-19 vaccines in preventing severe disease, hospitalizations, and deaths. It also underscores the importance of robust data collection and reporting at the state level to monitor vaccine effectiveness and inform public health policies. As the pandemic continues to evolve, it is essential to remain informed about the latest data and trends to make informed decisions about personal protective measures and vaccination status.

Biden Signs $1.9 Trillion Covid-19 Relief Bill into Law: "Help Is Here," President Says

FDA and CDC Lift Recommended Pause on Johnson & Johnson COVID-19 Vaccine: Benefits Outweigh Risks

The U.S. Food and Drug Administration (FDA) and the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) announced today that the recommended pause on the use of the Johnson & Johnson (Janssen) COVID-19 Vaccine in the United States is being lifted. This decision comes after a thorough safety review by medical and scientific teams from both agencies.

The pause was initially recommended on April 13, 2021, following reports of six cases of a rare and severe type of blood clot, known as thrombosis-thrombocytopenia syndrome (TTS), occurring in individuals after receiving the Janssen COVID-19 Vaccine.

"Safety is our top priority," said Acting FDA Commissioner Janet Woodcock, M.D. "Throughout this process, we have been working closely with the CDC and other public health partners to assess the benefits and risks of the Janssen COVID-19 Vaccine. Based on the available data, we have found that the vaccine's benefits in preventing COVID-19 outweigh the risks of TTS for individuals 18 years of age and older."

CDC Director Dr. Rochelle P. Walensky shared similar sentiments, "The COVID-19 pandemic continues to pose a serious public health threat to the United States and around the world. The Moderna and Pfizer-BioNTech vaccines have demonstrated excellent safety and efficacy, and we encourage all eligible Americans to get vaccinated with these vaccines. However, the Janssen COVID-19 Vaccine also plays an important role in preventing COVID-19, and the available data show that the vaccine's benefits outweigh its known and potential risks."

During the pause, the FDA and CDC conducted an extensive review of available data, assessed risks, and provided outreach to healthcare providers to ensure they had the most up-to-date information on the vaccine and TTS.

The data suggest that the chance of TTS occurring is very low. According to the CDC, as of May 7, 2021, a total of 15 cases of TTS have been reported to the Vaccine Adverse Event Reporting System (VAERS), all in women aged between 18 and 59 years.

To help healthcare providers and vaccine recipients better understand the risks associated with the Janssen COVID-19 Vaccine, the FDA and CDC have revised the vaccine's fact sheet to include information about TTS.

The CDC's Advisory Committee on Immunization Practices (ACIP) has also reviewed the latest data on TTS and reaffirmed its recommendation that the benefits of the Janssen COVID-19 Vaccine outweigh its known and potential risks for individuals 18 years of age and older.

"We understand that this pause may have caused concern and confusion, but we want to assure the American people that we take all reports of adverse events following vaccination seriously," said Dr. Walensky. "Our vaccine safety systems are working. We encourage people to consult their healthcare providers with any questions or concerns they may have about vaccines, including the Janssen COVID-19 Vaccine."

"We will continue to monitor the safety of COVID-19 vaccines closely," emphasized Acting FDA Commissioner Woodcock. "We have robust safety monitoring systems in place, and we will continue to work with our public health partners to ensure the American people have access to safe and effective vaccines."

The FDA, CDC, and other public health partners will continue to provide updates as more information becomes available. For more information about COVID-19 vaccines, visit the FDA's website at www.fda.gov/covid19vaccines and the CDC's website at www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/vaccines/index.html.

NIH-Supported Clinical Trial Shows AstraZeneca's COVID-19 Vaccine, AZD1222, Provides 78.9% Efficacy and 100% Protection Against Severe Disease or Hospitalization

FDA Authorizes Emergency Use of Pfizer's Paxlovid as First Oral Antiviral for COVID-19 Treatment

The drug works by inhibiting a SARS-CoV-2 protein, preventing virus replication, with ritonavir prolonging its effect.

"Vaccination remains the most effective way to prevent COVID-19," emphasized Cavazzoni. "Today's authorization provides an additional tool for healthcare providers to use in treating those at high risk of progressing to severe disease."

WHO Affirms Importance of COVID-19 Vaccines: Training the Immune System and Boosting Protection

Vaccines represent an essential tool in the arsenal against SARS-CoV-2, as they train the immune system to recognize and fight the virus without causing the disease.

Once administered, COVID-19 vaccines function by stimulating an immune response that recognizes and neutralizes the SARS-CoV-2 virus. This response triggers the production of antibodies, which are proteins that help the body combat the virus. These antibodies remain in the body, providing protection against future infection or, at the very least, reducing the severity of symptoms if the individual is exposed to the virus.

Individuals who have previously been infected with SARS-CoV-2 should still consider getting vaccinated, as doing so can boost their immune response and provide longer-lasting protection. The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) and WHO encourage these individuals to consult with their healthcare providers to determine their eligibility for vaccination.

Following vaccination, recipients are advised to stay at the vaccination site for 15 to 30 minutes for observation. This precautionary measure allows healthcare professionals to monitor individuals for any possible reactions to the vaccine, ensuring their safety and well-being.

Although COVID-19 vaccines can have mild-to-moderate side effects, these reactions typically resolve within a few days. Common side effects include pain, redness, and swelling at the injection site, as well as fever, fatigue, and body aches. These symptoms are a normal part of the immune response and indicate that the body is building protection against the virus.

Some COVID-19 vaccines, such as Pfizer-BioNTech and Moderna, require two doses for maximum efficacy. The recommended interval between doses is 21 to 28 days, with the possibility of extending this interval based on further evidence. WHO advises using vaccines from the same manufacturer for both doses, but flexibility may be considered in specific circumstances.

Clinical trials involving tens of thousands of participants have shown COVID-19 vaccines to be safe and effective at preventing severe disease and hospitalization. These trials have demonstrated that the benefits of vaccination far outweigh the risks, making vaccines a crucial component in the global response to the COVID-19 pandemic.

The longevity of protection provided by COVID-19 vaccines and the potential for vaccinated individuals to transmit the virus are still under investigation. While current evidence suggests that vaccines significantly reduce the risk of transmission, further research is needed to fully understand the role of vaccination in preventing the spread of SARS-CoV-2.

Despite the rollout of COVID-19 vaccines, it is essential to continue following recommended measures to reduce the spread of the virus. These measures include wearing masks, practicing social distancing, avoiding large gatherings, and washing hands frequently. By adhering to these guidelines, individuals can help protect themselves and those around them from infection.

The development and distribution of COVID-19 vaccines represent a significant achievement in the global fight against the pandemic. However, it is important to remember that the end of the crisis is not yet in sight. Continued efforts are needed to ensure equitable distribution of vaccines, address vaccine hesitancy, and encourage the adoption of proven preventative measures.

As the world moves towards a post-pandemic future, vaccines will play a crucial role in restoring normalcy and preserving the health and well-being of communities around the globe. WHO remains committed to supporting countries in their efforts to secure and administer vaccines, as well as advocating for equitable access to these vital resources.

The rapid development and deployment of COVID-19 vaccines represent a testament to the power of science, collaboration, and resilience in the face of adversity. This achievement serves as a reminder of the importance of investing in research and development, particularly in the context of public health emergencies.

WHO Designates Omicron (B.1.1.529) as a Variant of Concern: Increased Surveillance, Research, and Public Health Measures Urged

The World Health Organization (WHO) announced on 26 November 2021 that it has designated the B.1.1.529 SARS-CoV-2 variant, initially identified in South Africa, as a Variant of Concern (VOC), which it has named Omicron. This decision comes in response to the growing number of reported cases and several mutations that may impact transmissibility and disease severity.

Preliminary data suggests that Omicron harbors numerous mutations in the spike protein, the part of the virus that attaches to human cells. Among these changes are deletions, insertions, and substitutions, some of which have been observed in other variants of concern, such as Delta. However, the precise implications of these mutations for transmissibility, disease severity, and vaccine effectiveness are not yet fully understood.

Although it is currently unclear if Omicron is more transmissible or causes more severe disease than other variants, such as Delta, there is some preliminary evidence suggesting an increased risk of reinfection with Omicron compared to other VOCs. This is a cause for concern as it may complicate efforts to control the pandemic.

Vaccines continue to be a critical tool in reducing severe disease and death, including against the Delta variant. WHO emphasizes the importance of maintaining high vaccination coverage, particularly in at-risk populations, to minimize the potential impact of Omicron and other VOCs.

Laboratory studies are ongoing to assess the impact of Omicron on various diagnostic tests and current treatments, including PCR tests, rapid antigen tests, and monoclonal antibodies. Preliminary results indicate that PCR tests can still detect Omicron, providing an essential foundation for ongoing surveillance efforts.

WHO is coordinating global research efforts to better understand the characteristics and impact of Omicron. The organization is working closely with member states, collaborating on genomic sequencing, clinical studies, and modeling efforts to evaluate the implications of this new VOC.

In light of the evolving situation, WHO strongly recommends countries enhance their surveillance efforts, share data, report cases, and conduct investigations to understand the impact of Omicron on transmission dynamics, disease severity, and vaccine effectiveness.

Additionally, WHO urges countries to implement effective public health measures, such as physical distancing, wearing masks, and expanding access to COVID-19 vaccines and treatments, particularly in low- and middle-income countries where equity remains a significant concern.

As the global community grapples with the emergence of Omicron, it is essential that individuals remain vigilant and committed to preventive measures. WHO Designates B.1.1.529 SARS-CoV-2 Variant as a Variant of Concern (VOC), Named Omicron

The World Health Organization (WHO) Technical Advisory Group on SARS-CoV-2 Virus Evolution (TAG-VE) held an emergency meeting on 26 November 2021 to assess the newly identified SARS-CoV-2 variant, B.1.1.529. This variant was first reported by South Africa to WHO on 24 November 2021, with the first known infection dating back to 9 November 2021.

The B.1.1.529 variant is characterized by a large number of mutations. Preliminary evidence from South Africa suggests an increased risk of reinfection with this variant. Cases of B.1.1.529 are on the rise in almost all provinces in South Africa, raising global concerns.

Current SARS-CoV-2 PCR diagnostics are capable of detecting this variant. Notably, the S gene target failure in one PCR test can serve as a marker for the detection of the B.1.1.529 variant. WHO is closely monitoring the situation and will provide updates on new findings as they become available.

The TAG-VE carefully evaluated the available data and advised that the B.1.1.529 variant should be designated as a Variant of Concern (VOC). This designation carries a higher level of concern due to its potential impact on the effectiveness of current countermeasures, such as diagnostics, therapeutics, and vaccines. The new variant has been named Omicron (Omicron SARS-CoV-2).

WHO has communicated the designation of Omicron as a VOC to the global community. Countries are requested to enhance their surveillance, sequencing, and reporting of cases associated with the VOC. This is essential to monitor the spread of the variant and better understand its characteristics and potential impact.

Individuals are reminded to continue adhering to public health measures, such as wearing masks, practicing social distancing, and maintaining good hand hygiene. These measures help reduce the transmission of all SARS-CoV-2 variants, including Omicron.

Vaccination is a critical tool in the fight against COVID-19 and its variants. WHO encourages all countries to increase their vaccination efforts to protect their populations. Vaccines have been shown to be effective in preventing severe disease and hospitalization due to SARS-CoV-2 infection.

Definitions for SARS-CoV-2 Variant of Interest (VOI) and Variant of Concern (VOC) are as follows:

  1. Variant of Interest (VOI): A SARS-CoV-2 variant with genetic changes that are predicted or known to affect virus characteristics such as transmissibility, disease severity, or diagnostic and therapeutic countermeasures.
  2. Variant of Concern (VOC): A SARS-CoV-2 variant for which there is evidence of an increase in transmissibility, more severe disease (e.g., increased hospitalization or death), significant reduction in efficacy of countermeasures (such as vaccines), or diagnostic detection failures.

WHO continues to closely monitor the global situation regarding SARS-CoV-2 and its variants. Updates on the Omicron variant, as well as other emerging variants, will be shared as new information becomes available. The organization remains committed to supporting countries in their efforts to mitigate the impact of COVID-19 and its variants.

NIH Initiates Clinical Trial to Evaluate Safety and Immunogenicity of Mixed Booster COVID-19 Vaccine Regimens

The National Institutes of Health (NIH), through its National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases (NIAID), has launched a Phase 1/2 clinical trial to assess the safety, tolerability, and immunogenicity of various mixed booster COVID-19 vaccine regimens. This study, led and funded by the NIAID, is being carried out in collaboration with the Infectious Diseases Clinical Research Consortium (IDCRC).

Anthony S. Fauci, M.D., Director of the NIAID, emphasized the importance of preparing for potential booster shots due to waning immunity and the ongoing evolution of the virus. "As we continue to monitor the real-world effectiveness of the authorized COVID-19 vaccines, it's crucial that we also investigate the safety and efficacy of various booster combinations," said Dr. Fauci. "This trial is an essential step toward understanding the optimal vaccine regimens for the evolving pandemic."

The clinical trial, named "A Randomized Phase 1/2 Study to Evaluate the Safety, Tolerability, and Immunogenicity of Mixed Schedule COVID-19 Vaccines," is being conducted at Baylor College of Medicine in Houston, Texas, and the University of Maryland, College Park. Robert L. Atmar, M.D., Principal Investigator at Baylor College of Medicine, and Kirsten E. Lyke, M.D., Principal Investigator at the University of Maryland, College Park, will lead the study.

Initially, 150 participants who have received one of the three Food and Drug Administration (FDA) Emergency Use Authorized (EUA) COVID-19 vaccines – Pfizer-BioNTech, Moderna, or Johnson & Johnson – will receive a booster dose of the Moderna vaccine. Participants will be followed for a year post-vaccination for safety monitoring, side effects, and immune response evaluations.

The trial includes separate cohorts for individuals initially unvaccinated, who will then receive the two-dose Moderna vaccine regimen. An adaptive design of the trial may introduce new arms as additional vaccines receive EUA or variant vaccines become available. This flexibility allows the study to address the rapidly changing COVID-19 vaccine landscape.

"This clinical trial represents an essential contribution to the global understanding of COVID-19 vaccines," said Dr. Atmar. "As we work to protect people from this virus, it's crucial to evaluate the safety and efficacy of various vaccine combinations and schedules."

Dr. Lyke echoed Dr. Atmar's sentiments: "The ability to adapt the study design as new vaccines and variants emerge ensures that we can provide valuable data to inform public health policy on using mixed vaccine schedules if booster doses become necessary."

Initial results from the trial are expected in late summer 2021, and trial information can be found on clinicaltrials.gov under identifier NCT04889209. The NIH is the primary federal agency for medical research in the U.S., focusing on infectious, immune-mediated diseases, and other illnesses.

Pfizer-BioNTech and Moderna COVID-19 Vaccines: Two Doses for Maximum Protection vs. Johnson & Johnson's Single-Dose Advantage

The Pfizer-BioNTech and Moderna COVID-19 vaccines have been instrumental in the global fight against the coronavirus pandemic. While both these vaccines require two doses for full efficacy, the Johnson & Johnson (J&J) vaccine stands out with its single-dose advantage. Understanding the differences between these vaccines, their efficacy, and dosing schedules is crucial in navigating the ongoing vaccine rollout.

The Pfizer-BioNTech and Moderna vaccines use messenger RNA (mRNA) technology to trigger an immune response against the SARS-CoV-2 virus. mRNA acts like a set of instructions that instructs the body's cells to produce a specific protein, in this case, a piece of the coronavirus. The immune system then recognizes these proteins as foreign invaders and produces an immune response. Initial immunity is observed after the first dose of both Pfizer-BioNTech (52-91% effective) and Moderna (50.8-92.1% effective) vaccines. However, full immunity from these vaccines typically takes around 2 weeks after the second dose. The second dose of the Pfizer-BioNTech vaccine is administered 3 weeks after the first, while Moderna's second dose comes 4 weeks after the first. The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) allows the second dose to be administered up to 4 days earlier than recommended or up to 6 weeks (42 days) after the first dose in certain situations.

The discussions about delaying or eliminating the second dose to increase vaccine coverage have raised concerns about long-term immunity and variant emergence. The CDC does not recommend mixing Pfizer and Moderna vaccines; the same product should be used for both doses to ensure optimal immune response. Vaccine effectiveness is 95% for Pfizer-BioNTech and 94.1% for Moderna after the second dose. These high efficacy rates make it essential to prioritize the timely administration of the full recommended dosing schedule to protect as many people as possible against the virus and its potential variants.

It is essential to emphasize that the benefits of COVID-19 vaccines, including the prevention of severe illness, hospitalization, and death, far outweigh the risks. Concerns about the potential severity of the virus for children are high, with 57% of parents expressing worry that their child may get seriously sick from coronavirus. This concern is more pronounced among Hispanic and lower-income parents.

The KFF report also highlights the importance of addressing vaccine hesitancy, particularly among parents of younger children. Outreach efforts that focus on building trust and providing accurate information about the safety and efficacy of the vaccines could play a crucial role in increasing vaccination rates among this demographic.

Schools can also take steps to mitigate the spread of COVID-19 by implementing robust testing programs, maintaining mask mandates, and providing clear communication to families about exposure incidents and quarantine protocols. These measures can help parents feel more confident in sending their children to school and contribute to a safer learning environment.

The KFF COVID-19 Vaccine Monitor provides valuable insights into parents' attitudes and experiences regarding COVID-19 vaccines and school safety. As the pandemic continues to evolve, it is essential to stay informed about these trends and the factors that influence them. By working together to address vaccine hesitancy and support schools' efforts to limit the spread of COVID-19, we can help protect the health and well-being of our children and communities.

Novavax COVID-19 Vaccine Shines in Phase 3 Trials with 90.4% Efficacy and 100% Protection against Severe Disease

In a significant breakthrough in the fight against COVID-19, the Novavax vaccine (NVX-CoV2373) has demonstrated impressive results in a Phase 3 clinical trial. The trial, known as PREVENT-19, was funded by the Biomedical Advanced Research and Development Authority (BARDA) and the National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases (NIAID) and enrolled 29,960 volunteers in the U.S. and Mexico. The study showed that the vaccine had an efficacy rate of 90.4% in preventing symptomatic COVID-19 infections.

The trial results were even more promising when it came to protection against moderate and severe disease. NVX-CoV2373 showed 100% efficacy in preventing these more severe cases of COVID-19. This is particularly significant as severe disease can lead to hospitalization and even death.

The vaccine also proved effective in high-risk individuals, including those aged 65 or older and those under 65 with certain comorbidities. NVX-CoV2373 showed an efficacy rate of 91.0% in this population. These findings are particularly important as older adults and those with underlying health conditions are at greater risk for severe disease and complications from COVID-19.

The most common side effects reported in the trial were mild-to-moderate injection site pain, fatigue, headache, and muscle pain, which lasted less than two days. These side effects are similar to those reported with other COVID-19 vaccines and are generally considered to be mild and short-lived.

The PREVENT-19 trial used a 2:1 ratio for vaccine to placebo distribution and maintained a study blind to ensure that participants and investigators did not know who received the vaccine. The study results were based on 77 symptomatic COVID-19 cases observed, with 63 in the placebo group and 14 in the vaccine group.

NVX-CoV2373 uses recombinant protein nanoparticle technology and includes an adjuvant to enhance the immune response. This technology is different from the messenger RNA (mRNA) technology used in the Pfizer-BioNTech and Moderna vaccines. In May 2021, the PREVENT-19 trial expanded to include adolescents aged 12-17. The COVID-19 Prevention Network (CoVPN) and various health organizations are involved in facilitating and overseeing the trial. With these promising results, NVX-CoV2373 is poised to become another valuable tool in the global fight against COVID-19.

Single Dose Vaccine Effectiveness: A Cautionary Tale from Pfizer to Sinopharm

"Early signs of efficacy are not definitive proof of immunity," she cautioned in a recent interview with BBC News. This comes as various studies and estimates regarding the effectiveness of single doses of different vaccines have emerged.

One of the most recent debates revolves around Pfizer-BioNTech's initial claim of a 52% efficacy rate for their vaccine after a single dose. This estimate was criticized by Professor Nachman Ash, who coordinated Israel's Covid-19 response, as overly optimistic. "We cannot rely on a single-dose vaccine for herd immunity," he told BBC News. "The data we have from Israel shows a 33% effectiveness in preventing infection after a single dose, which is significantly lower than Pfizer's initial estimate."

Direct Quote: "We cannot rely on a single-dose vaccine for herd immunity." - Professor Nachman Ash

The Israeli study, conducted by Clalit Health Services, found that Pfizer's vaccine offered 33% protection against Covid-19 infection after one dose. However, it's important to note that these results are not peer-reviewed and were based on observations two weeks post-vaccination. Meanwhile, the Oxford-AstraZeneca vaccine showed 64.1% protection against Covid-19 infection after a single dose, according to data from the University of Oxford. AstraZeneca's phase III trial data indicates 70% protection against mild or moderate illness after one dose, extending several months before a booster is needed.

Moderna claimed an 80.2% efficacy rate after one dose from their FDA submission, but no data on long-term immunity from a single dose has been released. Sinovac's CoronaVac showed varied efficacy in trials across Turkey, Indonesia, and Brazil, but lacks single dose data. Sinopharm's BBIBP-CorV vaccine has been claimed to be 79% effective after two doses, but there is no international verification of this claim. The UAE claimed the Sinopharm vaccine to be 86% effective according to a press release, but no details on single dose protection have been provided.

As the world continues to grapple with the Covid-19 pandemic, understanding the true effectiveness of single dose vaccines is crucial. While promising results have emerged, it's essential to remember that early data is not definitive proof of long-term immunity and that continued monitoring and peer-reviewed research are necessary to ensure the accuracy and reliability of vaccine efficacy estimates.

"The K417N mutation is present in the receptor binding domain of the spike protein, which is the part of the virus that interacts with human cells," explains Dr. Kang.

The delta plus variant was first identified in India in December 2020. It has since been detected in several countries, including the UK, where it accounted for 6% of COVID-19 cases in May 2021. In the US, the delta plus variant accounted for less than 1% of COVID-19 cases in May, according to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC).

Despite the growing concerns, there's no clear evidence that delta plus has gained a foothold over existing variants. Dr. Angus notes, "It's important to remember that we're dealing with a highly mutable virus, and new variants will continue to emerge. But at this point, there's no indication that delta plus is more transmissible or more severe than the delta variant."

The potential exists for future variants to evade vaccines and cause more severe disease. Dr. Fauci cautions, "We need to remain vigilant and continue to monitor the situation closely. The best way to prevent the emergence of new variants is to get as many people vaccinated as possible."

In conclusion, the delta plus variant is a new concern in the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic. Facebook's Massive Outage: A Tale of Misdirected Data and Configuration Changes

On Monday, the digital world was thrown into chaos as Facebook, along with its subsidiaries Instagram and WhatsApp, experienced a massive outage that left billions of users globally disconnected from their favorite social media platforms. The cause of the outage, initially attributed to issues with the Border Gateway Protocol (BGP), sent shockwaves through the tech community as this crucial system responsible for directing internet traffic was put under the spotlight.

BGP is likened to a map guiding data packets across various autonomous systems to reach their destination efficiently. The internet is divided into autonomous systems, which include Internet Service Providers (ISPs), companies, or governments, and BGP helps navigate data through these systems. Errors in BGP can misroute traffic, similar to outdated or wrong directions on a map leading drivers astray.

Facebook's outage, however, was not primarily about external routing but rather internal communication. Facebook has its own BGP system for fast updates within its data centers, but the outage was a result of a configuration change on the backbone routers that led to a cascading communication failure between data centers.

BGP and Domain Name System (DNS) work hand in hand. DNS identifies the IP address, and BGP finds the best route to that address. DNS translates human-readable domain names into machine-readable IP addresses, while BGP ensures these IP addresses reach their destination via the most efficient route.

The Facebook incident was not an isolated case. Past BGP mishaps have caused global access issues to sites like YouTube and even resulted in ISPs accidentally hijacking traffic. In 2008, a BGP error caused YouTube to become inaccessible, while in 2018, Pakistan's national telecommunications authority accidentally leaked its BGP routes, causing global internet access issues.

Configuration changes are a common cause of BGP disruptions. In 2018, Google experienced a BGP disruption due to an incorrectly announced route, resulting in a brief disruption of its services. Similarly, in 2019, Facebook's WhatsApp messaging service was disrupted due to a BGP misconfiguration.

Facebook's outage was a reminder of the importance of proper configuration management and redundancy in BGP systems. Misconfigurations can lead to significant disruptions and can take hours, if not days, to resolve.

The consequences of the Facebook outage were far-reaching, with businesses relying on these platforms for customer engagement and communication scrambling to find alternatives. The incident served as a wake-up call for organizations to have contingency plans in place to mitigate the impact of such disruptions.

Facebook quickly acknowledged the issue and assured users that they were working to resolve it. The social media giant also took to its platforms to provide updates on the progress being made to restore services.

As the dust settles on Facebook's massive outage, the tech community remains vigilant, learning valuable lessons from this incident. The importance of proper configuration management, redundancy, and effective communication during disruptions cannot be overstated. Facebook's misfortune serves as a reminder that even the largest tech companies are not immune to the complexities and uncertainties of the internet.

In response, community oversight boards and changes in policies are being proposed to protect officers who report misconduct and hold their departments accountable. Minnesota Governor Tim Walz recently signed into law a package of police accountability bills, including measures to create a statewide police oversight agency and end qualified immunity for police officers (Star Tribune, 2021).

A shift in accountability is also being suggested, from taxpayers to police officers and their departments. Ending qualified immunity and creating liability insurances for police departments can help ensure that officers are held accountable for their actions. However, these measures must be accompanied by broader systemic changes to address police brutality and the pursuit of an equitable democracy.

The Chauvin trial and the larger issue of police brutality reflect a broader issue of systemic racial inequality in the criminal justice system. As the Reverend Al Sharpton noted in his eulogy for George Floyd, "We are here because we are the last people who are supposed to be unprotected. We are the hunted, not the hunters" (NPR, 2021).

In the words of Angela Davis, "Prisons do not disappear problems; they disappear human beings" (Davis, 1971). The criminal justice system, which disproportionately targets and harms communities of color, must be transformed to prioritize rehabilitation, community restoration, and racial equity. We must continue to demand justice for all victims of police brutality and work towards a society where all people are truly equal under the law.

In the words of Martin Luther King Jr., "The arc of the moral universe is long, but it bends towards justice" (King, 1958). Let us continue to bend that arc.

MINNEAPOLIS (AP) – Former Minneapolis police officer Derek Chauvin declined to testify in his own defense during the trial over the death of George Floyd, instead invoking his Fifth Amendment right against self-incrimination on Friday.

The defense, meanwhile, aimed to present Chauvin's actions as reasonable and suggested Floyd's death was due to health issues and drug use. The only time Chauvin has been heard defending himself was through body-camera footage shown to the jury.

Prosecutors called several use-of-force experts who testified that Chauvin's use of force against Floyd was excessive and violated department policy. Defense witnesses testified that Chauvin followed his training and that Floyd's death was not caused by the officer's actions.

One of the prosecution's key witnesses was Dr. Martin Tobin, a pulmonologist who testified that the way Floyd was pinned to the pavement prevented him from getting enough oxygen. MINNEAPOLIS (AP) – Juror Brandon Mitchell Describes Relaxed Deliberations, Emotional Toll in Derek Chauvin Trial

MINNEAPOLIS (AP) – Brandon Mitchell, the first juror to speak publicly about the Derek Chauvin trial, described the deliberations as relaxed and methodical, leading to a unanimous conviction in the death of George Floyd.

"The deliberations were methodical and professional," Mitchell said in an interview Wednesday. "We listened carefully to each other's perspectives and made our decision based on the facts presented in the trial."

Mitchell, a 31-year-old transportation supervisor, compared the emotional toll of the trial to attending a funeral every day. "It was an intense and emotional experience," he said. "But we were all focused on doing the right thing and making sure justice was served."

The jury convicted Chauvin of second- and third-degree murder and second-degree manslaughter on April 20, 2021.

Mitchell highlighted the importance of video evidence and the testimony of Dr. Martin Tobin, a breathing expert, in reaching the verdict. "The video evidence was compelling, and Dr. Tobin's testimony really helped us understand what was happening to George Floyd during those final moments," he said.

Jurors took a preliminary vote on manslaughter first, then moved on to third-degree murder, and finally agreed on second-degree murder. "It was a process of elimination," Mitchell explained. "We started with the least serious charge and worked our way up to the most serious one."

Mitchell thought the defense's strategy of portraying bystanders as a threat was ineffective since they didn't appear hostile. "The defense tried to make it seem like the bystanders were a threat, but we could all see that they were just concerned citizens trying to help," he said.

Chauvin's choice not to testify did not impact the trial's outcome, according to Mitchell. "His decision not to testify didn't really factor into our deliberations," he said. "We based our decision on the evidence presented in the trial, not on what Derek Chauvin had to say."

Mitchell felt no pressure to reach a verdict to prevent potential violent protests. "There was no pressure from outside sources to rush to a decision," he said. "We took our time and made sure we were making the right decision based on the facts presented in the trial."

Mitchell was careful to hide his involvement in the trial from his basketball team and conversed little about the case with his family. "I didn't want anyone to know I was on the jury until after the trial was over," he said. "I didn't want any outside influences to affect my decision-making."

Mitchell refrained from predicting the outcome for the other three officers charged in Floyd's death, suggesting their trials might present different challenges. "Each case is unique, and I can't speak to what will happen in the other officers' trials," he said. "We focused on the evidence presented in Derek Chauvin's trial and made our decision based on that."

Inaccurate Initial Police Reports on Fatal Encounters Highlighted by George Floyd Case

However, video evidence from bystanders has been critical in revealing the truth in several cases, such as Eric Garner's and Walter Scott's deaths.

With about 80% of large police departments now using body cameras, the issue of inaccurate initial reports has gained new attention. Storage costs are high, and footage release can be delayed, but recent trends show police and prosecutors releasing body camera footage more swiftly to address public outcry and demands for transparency.

Minneapolis police spokesperson John Elder admitted the initial statement on Floyd's death was inaccurate but explained that they were unable to correct it immediately due to the ongoing investigation. He stated, "We understand the concerns about the initial statement, and we are committed to providing accurate and complete information as soon as possible."

The quick release of body camera footage in recent cases, such as the fatal shooting of 16-year-old Ma'Khia Bryant in Columbus, Ohio, and the shooting of Anthony J. Thompson Jr. in Knoxville, Tennessee, has helped address discrepancies between initial reports and video evidence.

Columbus Police Chief Elaine Bryant explained their decision to release the footage quickly, stating, "Transparency is crucial in building trust between law enforcement and the communities we serve." In Knoxville, District Attorney Charme Allen released the body camera footage after public pressure, contradicting initial statements that Thompson had been armed and posed a threat.

Despite these efforts, concerns about inaccurate initial police reports persist, highlighting the need for ongoing training, accountability, and transparency in law enforcement.

Ex-Officer Derek Chauvin Faces Uncertain Sentence in George Floyd's Death

Under Minnesota law, Chauvin will only be sentenced for the most serious charge, second-degree murder, which has a maximum sentence of 40 years. But experts predict Chauvin is unlikely to receive the maximum sentence.

Mary Moriarty, a former Hennepin County chief public defender, stated, "It's really hard to imagine that he's going to get the maximum sentence."

Keith Ellison, Minnesota Attorney General, acknowledged the potential for a lengthy sentence during a press conference: "The law says he could get up to 40 years... I'm not going to speculate."

Mark Osler, a professor at the University of St. Thomas School of Law, added, "It's rare for someone to get the maximum sentence." He explained that sentencing guidelines are more likely to influence the outcome.

Minnesota's sentencing guidelines suggest a presumptive sentence of 12 1/2 years for someone with no criminal record, like Chauvin. However, the prosecution is seeking an 'upward departure' from the guidelines due to aggravating factors such as Floyd's vulnerability and the presence of children during the crime.

Osler explained, "The expectation is that an upward departure sentence should not exceed double the guideline range." That would mean a maximum sentence of 25 years.

Chauvin can expect to serve two-thirds of his sentence in prison with good behavior, the rest potentially on supervised release. Moriarty emphasized the importance of behavior during incarceration, stating, "The way that person behaves in prison can make a big difference in the length of time they spend in prison."

Both defense and prosecution will submit briefs on aggravating factors, which will influence Judge Cahill's sentencing decision. Ted Sampsell-Jones, a professor at Mitchell Hamline School of Law, noted, "Judges are not bound by those sentencing guidelines, but they do use them as a guideline."

A pre-sentence investigation report, typically including personal history and the offense's impact, will also be considered in the sentencing. Moriarty stressed, "The pre-sentence investigation is a very important part of the sentencing process."

Regarding Chauvin's potential statement during the sentencing hearing, Sampsell-Jones said, "There's a good chance he won't say anything... Because anything he says could be used against him in an appeal."

Ellison expressed confidence in the justice system's ability to deliver an appropriate sentence: "The jury's verdict was just the first step. Now, the court is going to determine what the sentence is going to be."

Minnesota Judge Finds Aggravating Factors in George Floyd's Death, Allowing for Longer Sentence for Derek Chauvin

MINNEAPOLIS (AP) – A Minnesota judge ruled on Friday that there were aggravating factors in the death of George Floyd, paving the way for a possible longer sentence for former Minneapolis police officer Derek Chauvin.

Judge Peter Cahill, who presided over Chauvin's three-week trial, found that Chauvin abused his position as a police officer and treated Floyd with particular cruelty. The judge also noted the presence of children during the crime and Chauvin's role in a group during the offense.

"The court finds that aggravating factors have been proved by clear and convincing evidence," Cahill said during the hearing.

Chauvin, convicted of second-degree unintentional murder, third-degree murder, and second-degree manslaughter, will be sentenced on the most serious count on June 25. Legal experts speculate that Chauvin is unlikely to receive more than 30 years when sentenced.

Prosecutors asked for an upward departure in sentencing, citing Floyd's vulnerability and Chauvin's refusal to stop even after Floyd became unresponsive.

"The presence of children adds to the heinousness of this crime," prosecutor Matthew Frank said during the hearing. "Mr. Floyd was not just a man, he was not just a man in the street, he was a man in front of his young daughter."

Mark Osler, a professor at the University of St. Thomas School of Law in Minneapolis, said the judge's ruling on aggravating factors is significant.

"This is a critical moment because it gives the judge the option to sentence Chauvin above the guideline range," Osler said. "The judge has signaled that there are aggravating factors, which could lead to a longer sentence."

Defense attorney Eric Nelson argued against the finding of aggravating factors, stating that Chauvin was authorized to use reasonable force.

"Mr. Chauvin did not intentionally kill Mr. Floyd. He acted based on the information he had at the time," Nelson said during the hearing.

Cahill agreed with prosecutors on most points but did not find Floyd was particularly vulnerable due to his ability to struggle.

"Although the court does not find that Mr. Floyd was particularly vulnerable, the court does find that Mr. Chauvin's actions were particularly cruel," Cahill said.

Chauvin also faces federal charges alleging he violated Floyd's civil rights, which would run concurrently with any state sentence.

Osler said that the ruling on aggravating factors increases the likelihood that Chauvin will receive a longer sentence.

"It's important to remember that this is just one step in the process," Osler said. "The sentencing hearing is still to come, and the judge will have the final say on the length of Chauvin's sentence."

Cahill's ruling comes as the nation continues to grapple with the issue of police brutality and racial justice in the aftermath of Floyd's death last May. The case sparked widespread protests and calls for police reform across the country.

The sentencing hearing for Chauvin is scheduled for June 25.

Osler said that regardless of the length of Chauvin's sentence, the case will continue to serve as a catalyst for change.

"This case has brought attention to the issue of police brutality and the need for reform," Osler said. "It's important that we continue to have these conversations and work towards a more just and equitable society."

Floyd's death led to widespread protests, removal of Confederate statues, and reforms in policing practices across the country. The tragic event also sparked a global conversation about systemic racism and police brutality.

Sarah Fitzgerald, a Department of Corrections spokeswoman, confirmed that Chauvin would be taken into custody following the verdict and would be transported to the Ramsey County jail in St. Paul. He faces up to 40 years in prison.

President Biden also called on Congress to pass the George Floyd Justice in Policing Act, which would, among other things, ban chokeholds, create a national police registry, and limit qualified immunity for officers.

Two witnesses, Janay Henry and Jamee Haggard, testified about the emotional toll Floyd's death had on them and how they begged Chauvin to stop kneeling on Floyd's neck. The Justice Department announced an investigation into Minneapolis policing practices following the verdict. Civil rights attorney Ben Crump, who represented the Floyd family, called for similar investigations in other cities.

Hurricane Ida's Devastating Impact: Climate Change Amplifies Wetter, Slower Storms, Experts Warn

The global proportion of Category 3 to 5 hurricanes has been rising, according to data from NOAA.

As Ida made landfall, it produced over 15 inches of rain in parts of Louisiana, contributing to significant flooding, Scott Perrien, a hydrologist with the US Geological Survey, reported.

"The increased atmospheric moisture due to warming allows hurricanes to generate more rainfall, making flooding more severe," Perrien said.

Storm surges are worsening due to sea level rise, further amplifying the destructive impact of hurricanes, Paul Miller, Coastal Meteorology Scientist at Louisiana State University, explained.

"We're seeing more storm surges because of the sea level rise," Miller said. "That's a major issue for coastal communities."

In Louisiana, the coastal wetlands, a natural defense against storm surge, are disappearing at an alarming rate, worsening the effects of hurricanes like Ida.

"The loss of wetlands is a significant problem," Hayhoe said. "They act as a natural buffer against storm surges and can help mitigate some of the worst impacts of hurricanes."

Experts warn that rapid greenhouse gas emission reductions are necessary to mitigate the worst impacts of climate change on hurricane severity.

"If we don't take action to reduce greenhouse gas emissions, we're going to see even more severe hurricanes in the future," Kossin cautioned.

Hayhoe emphasized the urgency of the situation: "We need to act now to reduce our carbon footprint and limit the worst impacts of climate change on hurricanes."

The devastation wrought by Hurricane Ida serves as a stark reminder of the escalating threat climate change poses to coastal communities.

As the world grapples with the consequences of Ida and other extreme weather events, experts call for urgent action to address the root cause: human-caused climate change.

"We can't afford to ignore the science any longer," Hayhoe concluded. "The future of our communities and our planet depends on it."

"Katrina was bad, but this is worse," Justin Landry said. "We've been through storms before, but nothing like this. We just want to rebuild and get back to normal."

Recovery efforts are being hampered by slow insurance assessments and the wait for federal assistance funds. Residents are growing increasingly frustrated as they try to navigate the complex process of rebuilding their homes and lives.

Despite the severe devastation, long-time residents like Trufant Salvant express a strong emotional connection to their community and desire to rebuild.

"Ironton is more than just a town," Trufant Salvant said. "It's a part of who we are. We'll get through this, together."

As the community comes together to rebuild, the road to recovery is long and arduous. But for residents like Trufant Salvant, the determination to reclaim normalcy remains steadfast.

"We'll get there," she said. "It might take some time, but we'll get there."

In the meantime, the United Way of Southeast Louisiana and other organizations are urging people to donate what they can to help those in need. For more information on how to help, visit their website at unitedwaysela.org.

Hurricane Ida's Devastating Aftermath: Mississippi Highway Collapse, Alligator Attack, and Power Outages in Louisiana

Hurricane Ida, now a tropical storm, left a trail of destruction across Mississippi and Louisiana, claiming at least four lives and causing widespread damage. Cal Robertson, Mississippi Highway Patrol spokesperson, reported two fatalities and at least 10 injuries due to a highway collapse in Pearl River County, Mississippi.

In Louisiana, a 71-year-old man went missing after an alligator attack in floodwaters in St. Martin Parish. The incident underscored the unpredictable dangers of the storm's aftermath.

New Orleans, Louisiana's largest city, was hit hard, with widespread power outages compounding the effects of the ongoing heatwave on residents. "This is a tough day for our city," said Mayor LaToya Cantrell, urging residents to conserve water and stay cool.

Over 6,000 national guard members from multiple states were mobilized for rescue and relief efforts. "We're focusing on search and rescue, restoring critical infrastructure, and providing essential supplies," said Hokanson.

Ida made landfall as a category 4 storm on August 29, causing extensive damage and leading to flash flooding and tornadoes across several states. President Biden and federal officials coordinated with state and local authorities to provide storm assistance.

Cal Robertson shared details of the highway collapse in Mississippi. "A tractor-trailer loaded with debris slid off the bridge, causing it to collapse," he explained. "There were multiple vehicles involved, and we're still investigating the cause."

Governor Edwards described the alligator attack incident in Louisiana. "An elderly man was wading in floodwaters when he was attacked by an alligator. We're treating this as a missing persons case," he said.

Residents in New Orleans shared their experiences during the storm and its aftermath. "We've been without power for days, and it's getting hotter each day," said one resident. "But we're making it work, helping each other out."

President Biden pledged federal support for the storm-affected areas. "We'll be there to help rebuild and recover," he assured during a press conference. "Our thoughts are with the people of Louisiana and Mississippi during this difficult time."

Hurricane Ida's Devastating Blow to Louisiana's $2.4 Billion Seafood Industry: "It's Worse Than Katrina" - Lt. Gov. Billy Nungesser

NEW ORLEANS (AP) – In the aftermath of Hurricane Ida, Lt. Gov. Billy Nungesser, who oversees seafood promotion for Louisiana, described the storm's impact on the industry as significantly more damaging than Hurricane Katrina in 2005.

"It's worse than Katrina," Nungesser said, referring to the extensive damage inflicted on vessels and infrastructure, notably in areas like Lafitte, Houma, and Pointe-aux-Chenes. "The seafood industry is worth $2.4 billion and employs over 23,000 people. These communities are relying on us to help them recover and adapt."

At Motivatit Seafoods in Houma, where oyster production was already strained by environmental changes and past events, the damage was immense, according to Steven Voisin, who runs the family business. "We lost most of our oyster leases, and the damage to our processing facility and boats is substantial," Voisin shared, his voice heavy with emotion.

Dale Williams, a shrimper, symbolizes the challenges faced by individual fishing operations. "I've lost my boat, and now I need to figure out how to repair or replace it," he said, adding, "This is more than just a personal loss. It's a blow to the entire industry."

Acy Cooper, president of the Louisiana Shrimp Association, estimated that about half the shrimping fleet was destroyed in some parishes. "We're facing a long road to recovery," he acknowledged.

Pointe-aux-Chenes, a community reliant on fishing and tourism, hangs in the balance due to damage to rental houses and infrastructure. "We've lost our livelihoods and our homes," Patti Dardar, who works at a marina in the area, shared. "It's a struggle to keep our heads above water."

Mitch Jurisich, an oyster farmer, emphasized the significance of the impact on the oyster industry. "We were already dealing with environmental changes and storm damage," he said. "Now, we're facing an uncertain future."

The coronavirus pandemic significantly reduced demand for fresh seafood, exacerbating the challenges faced by Louisiana's seafood industry. "It's a perfect storm of economic pressures, environmental degradation, and climate change," Nungesser said. "But we won't give up. We'll rebuild, and we'll adapt. That's what Louisianans do."

Hurricane Ida's Wrath: Exposing the Intersection of Climate Disasters and Fossil Fuel Profiteering in New Orleans

Hurricane Ida's relentless onslaught on New Orleans served as a stark reminder of the inadequacy of our current infrastructure and ways of living in the face of intensifying climate disasters. Several electrical transformers blew out, and a key transmission tower collapsed, potentially leaving New Orleans without power for days or even weeks. The city's water pumps were also deprived of power, forcing residents to rely on self-generated electricity and a single turbine, with rainwater continuing to rise.

The devastating impact of Hurricane Ida on New Orleans highlights the urgent need to rethink our ways of building and living. The climate crisis is no longer a future threat; it's a present reality that demands bold action. However, the principal contributors to this crisis—fossil fuel companies, particularly oil majors—continue to maintain their high status in Louisiana. The intersection of climate disasters and the fossil fuel industry was underscored by Hurricane Ida's earliest landfall at Port Fourchon, a critical marine complex for the nation's oil supply. Moreover, Louisiana remains a stronghold for the petrochemical industry, with an estimated 600 refineries and chemical plants in the area affected by the storm.

As the local community grapples with the aftermath of Hurricane Ida, it's essential to acknowledge the environmental and health issues related to the density of refineries and chemical plants in the region, often referred to as 'Cancer Alley.' The community's heavy involvement in the fossil fuel industry further complicates the transition to more sustainable practices. This is not a problem unique to Louisiana; similar challenges can be found in communities across the country that have been built around extractive industries. However, it's crucial to recognize the disproportionate impact these industries have on marginalized communities, who bear the brunt of pollution and climate-related hazards.

Fossil fuel companies must be held accountable for their role in exacerbating the climate crisis and the resulting disasters. The costs of restitution for the damage caused by Hurricane Ida and other climate-related disasters should not fall on the shoulders of taxpayers or the most vulnerable communities. Instead, fossil fuel companies must be compelled to invest in a just transition to renewable energy and pay reparations for the harm they have caused. Only then can we begin to build a more equitable and sustainable future for all.

Remnants of Hurricane Ida Bring Tornadoes, Flooding, and Power Outages to Mid-Atlantic States

NEW YORK (AP) – The remnants of Hurricane Ida brought a new wave of destruction to the mid-Atlantic states on Wednesday, with at least two tornadoes, heavy winds, and drenching rains leaving a trail of devastation in their wake.

Sgt. Chris Levchak, a police sergeant in Delaware County, Pennsylvania, reported two tornadoes in the area. "We've had multiple calls for trees down, wires down, and structural damage," Levchak said. "The tornadoes came through quickly, but the damage they caused was significant."

In New Jersey, a U.S. Postal Service building's roof collapsed due to the heavy rains, and widespread flooding led to cars and roads being submerged. At Newark Liberty International Airport, significant flooding occurred, leading to the suspension of all flights and train service.

New York City saw record-breaking rainfall, with Central Park recording 3.15 inches of rain in one hour, breaking the previous record set by Tropical Storm Henri. Subway stations and tracks in the city were so flooded that the Metropolitan Transportation Authority suspended all service.

Gov. Phil Murphy declared a state of emergency in all of New Jersey's 21 counties, urging people to stay off flooded roads. "The situation is volatile and dangerous," Murphy said. "Please heed the warnings and stay safe."

Thousands were evacuated in Pennsylvania due to dangerous levels at a dam near Johnstown, known as "Flood City." Montgomery County Fire Chief Scott Goldstein urged residents to evacuate immediately. "The situation at the dam is critical," Goldstein said. "We cannot stress enough the importance of evacuating now."

Both the Wilmore and Hinckston Run Dams in Pennsylvania were monitored for stability due to high-hazard conditions. In Maryland and Virginia, at least one death and significant property damage were reported.

Tropical Storm Larry was forming off the coast of Africa, anticipated to become a major hurricane by Saturday. The National Hurricane Center urged residents in the potential path of the storm to prepare for heavy rains and strong winds.

"This storm is a reminder that we must always be prepared for the unexpected," said FEMA Administrator Deanne Criswell. "I urge all residents in the mid-Atlantic states to stay informed and follow the guidance of local officials."

As the remnants of Hurricane Ida continued to move north, the Mid-Atlantic states braced for the possibility of more flooding and power outages. The storm had already caused significant damage, leaving many residents wondering when they would be able to return home.

As the storm moved on, the Mid-Atlantic states worked to assess the damage and begin the long process of recovery. The remnants of Hurricane Ida were a stark reminder of the power of nature and the importance of being prepared for the unexpected.

"We've been through this before, and we'll get through it again," said Gov. Murphy. "But we cannot do it alone. I urge all residents to come together and support one another during this difficult time."

Alligator Found with Human Remains in Stomach Ends Search for Missing Louisiana Man

Sept 14 (Reuters) – A 504-pound alligator, believed to have attacked 71-year-old Timothy Satterlee Sr during Hurricane Ida, was found with human remains in its stomach, ending a two-week search for the missing man in Slidell, Louisiana, authorities said on Monday.

Captain Lance Vitter, spokesperson for the St. Tammany Parish Sheriff's Office, confirmed the discovery of Satterlee's remains during the alligator capture on Sunday. The sheriff's office will work with the coroner's office to verify the identity of the remains.

Satterlee was last seen checking storm damage outside his home on Aug. 29, the day after Hurricane Ida caused devastating flooding in the region.

"Our thoughts and prayers go out to the Satterlee family during this difficult time," Vitter said in a statement. "We appreciate the community's patience and support throughout this investigation."

The attack occurred near Satterlee's home, where wildlife agents spotted the alligator using a drone. Louisiana Department of Wildlife licensed nuisance hunters were called in to capture the reptile.

Satterlee's wife, Linda, was present during the attack and witnessed her husband being dragged into the water by the alligator. She lost one of his arms during the encounter.

"I tried to get help, but when I returned to the scene, Mr. Satterlee was gone," Linda Satterlee said in a statement released by the sheriff's office. "I've lived in this community for over 50 years, and Tim was a beloved pillar. He will be deeply missed."

The finding of human remains in the alligator's stomach came as a shock to the local community. The size of the alligator, which is unusual for the region, highlighted the severity of the attack.

"Alligators are a natural part of our ecosystem, but attacks on humans are rare," said Lt. Col. James Davidson, a spokesperson for the Louisiana Department of Wildlife and Fisheries. "Our thoughts are with the Satterlee family during this tragic time."

The St. Tammany Parish Sheriff's Office asked for privacy for the Satterlee family as they grieve the loss of their loved one. An investigation into the incident is ongoing.

FEMA Provides Over $1.7 Billion in Grants and Loans for Hurricane Ida Recovery in Louisiana

BATON ROUGE, La. – In the aftermath of Hurricane Ida's devastating impact on Louisiana, the Federal Emergency Management Agency (FEMA) has distributed more than $1.7 billion in federal grants and low-interest loans to aid in the recovery process. This aid has been distributed through various programs to both individuals and businesses affected by the hurricane.

As of October 2021, over $889 million in federal grants have been awarded to survivors, with an additional $816 million in low-interest loans. The National Flood Insurance Program (NFIP) has paid out $297 million in claims to survivors.

Assistance provided includes housing support, other needs assistance, and U.S. Small Business Administration (SBA) loans. Federal housing assistance has provided rental aid to over 179,000 homeowners and renters. Direct Temporary Housing assistance is offered in the 10 most impacted parishes.

Additionally, the U.S. Army Corps of Engineers has installed 33,200 "blue roofs" for temporary home repairs. These roofs provide a watertight barrier to prevent further damage while more permanent repairs are underway.

FEMA Disaster Recovery Centers have been visited by nearly 33,269 individuals seeking help. These centers provide a one-stop shop for survivors to meet with representatives from various federal, state, and local agencies to discuss their recovery needs.

Disaster Survivor Assistance teams have made over 143,544 home visits to help survivors apply for assistance and navigate the recovery process. These teams have been instrumental in ensuring that those in need receive the help they are entitled to.

The deadline for applying for FEMA assistance has been extended to November 29, 2021. Survivors can apply online at DisasterAssistance.gov or by calling 1-800-621-3362. These methods are available seven days a week, from 7 a.m. to 10 p.m. Central Time.

It is important for survivors to apply for assistance as soon as possible to ensure they receive the help they need in a timely manner. FEMA encourages all eligible individuals to apply for assistance, even if they have insurance. FEMA assistance is intended to supplement, not replace, insurance coverage.

FEMA continues to work closely with state, local, and tribal partners to ensure that those affected by Hurricane Ida receive the assistance they need to recover and rebuild their communities. The agency remains committed to providing support and resources to help survivors get back on their feet.

As the recovery process continues, FEMA will continue to provide updates on the progress being made and the resources being made available to survivors. For more information, visit the FEMA Hurricane Ida webpage at FEMA.gov/Hurricane-Ida.

Hurricane Ida and COVID-19 Surge Create 'Perfect Twin-Demic' in Houma, Louisiana: Healthcare Workers Pray for Protection
